<A NAME="toc_df1030_3"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>ITEM 4. SUBMISSION OF MATTERS TO A VOTE OF SECURITY HOLDERS    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Not applicable. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="df1030_item_x._executive_officers_of_the_company"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_df1030_4"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>ITEM X. EXECUTIVE OFFICERS OF THE COMPANY    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following are the executive officers of our Company: </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>Alexander R.C. Allan, </I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>59, is Executive Vice President of the Company and President and Chief Operating Officer, Europe, Eurasia and Middle
East. Mr.&nbsp;Allan joined Coca-Cola Bottling Company of Johannesburg in 1968 as an Internal Auditor. He was appointed the financial Controller for the Southern
Africa Division of The Coca-Cola Company in 1978 and Assistant Division Manager and Finance Manager of the Southern and Central Africa Division in 1986. From January&nbsp;1986 until
January&nbsp;1993, he served as the Managing Director of National Beverage Services (Pty)&nbsp;Ltd., a management and services company in South Africa. In January&nbsp;1993, he was appointed
President of the Middle East Division (renamed Middle East&nbsp;&amp; North Africa division in 1998). Mr.&nbsp;Allan was appointed Senior Vice President of the Company and President of the Asia Group
in November&nbsp;1999. In March&nbsp;2001, he was elected President and Chief Operating Officer of the newly created Asia strategic business unit of the Company. Mr.&nbsp;Allan was elected
Executive Vice President in April&nbsp;2001. He was appointed to his current position as of January&nbsp;1, 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>Alexander B. Cummings, Jr., </I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>47, is Executive Vice President of the Company and President and Chief Operating Officer, Africa.
Mr.&nbsp;Cummings joined the Company in 1997 as Deputy Region Manager, Nigeria based in Lagos, Nigeria. In 1998 he was made Managing Director/Region Manager, Nigeria. In 2000, Mr.&nbsp;Cummings
became President of the North West Africa Division based in Morocco and in 2001 became President of the Africa Group overseeing the entire African continent. Mr.&nbsp;Cummings was elected to his
current position in July&nbsp;2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>Douglas N. Daft, </I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>60, is Chairman of the Board of Directors and Chief Executive Officer of the Company. Mr.&nbsp;Daft has announced his
intention to retire from the Company at the end of 2004. In November&nbsp;1984, Mr.&nbsp;Daft was appointed President of the Central Pacific Division. In October&nbsp;1987, he was appointed
Senior Vice President of the Pacific Group of the International Business Sector. In December&nbsp;1988, he was named President of Coca-Cola (Japan) Company, Limited and President of the
North Pacific Division of the International Business Sector. In September&nbsp;1991, Mr.&nbsp;Daft was named President of the Pacific Group of the International Business Sector and in
October&nbsp;1991, he was elected Senior Vice President of the Company. He was appointed President of the Middle and Far East Group in January&nbsp;1995 and served in that capacity until
October&nbsp;1999 when he also was given responsibilities for the Africa Group and the Schweppes Beverages Division. He was elected President and Chief Operating Officer and a Director of the
Company in December&nbsp;1999. Mr.&nbsp;Daft was elected to his current positions in February&nbsp;2000. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>J. Alexander M. Douglas, Jr., </I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>42, is Senior Vice President and Chief Customer Officer of the Company. Mr.&nbsp;Douglas joined the
Company in January&nbsp;1988 as a District Sales Manager for the Foodservice Division of Coca-Cola USA. In May 1994, he was named Vice President of Coca-Cola USA, initially
assuming leadership of the CCE Sales&nbsp;&amp; Marketing Group and eventually assuming leadership of the entire North American Field Sales and Marketing Groups. In January&nbsp;2000,
Mr.&nbsp;Douglas was appointed President of the North American Division within the North America strategic business unit. Mr.&nbsp;Douglas was elected to his current position in
February&nbsp;2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>Gary P. Fayard, </I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>51, is Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of the Company. Mr.&nbsp;Fayard joined the Company in
April&nbsp;1994. In July&nbsp;1994, he was elected Vice President and Controller. In December&nbsp;1999, he was elected Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Prior to joining the
Company, Mr.&nbsp;Fayard was a partner with Ernst&nbsp;&amp; Young. Mr.&nbsp;Fayard was elected to his current position in February&nbsp;2003. </FONT></P>

</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>16</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=18,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=190154,FOLIO='16',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]DF1030A.;17',USER='JLAWRENA',CD='26-FEB-2004;17:40' -->
<A NAME="page_df1030_1_17"> </A>
<UL>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>Steven J. Heyer, </I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>51, was elected President and Chief Operating Officer of the Company in December&nbsp;2002. In addition, from
December&nbsp;2003 through February&nbsp;24, 2004, Mr.&nbsp;Heyer assumed direct leadership of the North America strategic business unit. Mr.&nbsp;Heyer joined the Company in April&nbsp;2001
as President and Chief Operating Officer, Coca-Cola Ventures and in April&nbsp;2002 assumed leadership responsibility for Latin America. In his current role, Mr.&nbsp;Heyer is
responsible for overseeing all of the Company's strategic business units, as well as the Company's marketing, innovation and customer management functions. Mr.&nbsp;Heyer joined the Company from AOL
Time Warner, where he served since 1996 as President and Chief Operating Officer of Turner Broadcasting System,&nbsp;Inc. Mr.&nbsp;Heyer joined Turner Broadcasting System,&nbsp;Inc. in 1994 as
President of Turner Broadcasting Sales,&nbsp;Inc. Prior to that, Mr.&nbsp;Heyer was President and Chief Operating Officer of Young&nbsp;&amp; Rubicam Advertising Worldwide, as well as Executive Vice
President of Young&nbsp;&amp; Rubicam,&nbsp;Inc. In addition, Mr.&nbsp;Heyer was for 15&nbsp;years with Booz Allen&nbsp;&amp; Hamilton,&nbsp;Inc. and served as Senior Vice President and Managing
Partner of the firm's New York office and leader of its Marketing Practice Worldwide. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>Donald R. Knauss, </I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>53, is President and Chief Operating Officer, Coca-Cola North America. Mr.&nbsp;Knauss joined the Company in 1994 as
Senior Vice President of Marketing for The Minute Maid Company, and was named Senior Vice President and General Manager, U.S. Division in 1996. He served from March&nbsp;1998 until
January&nbsp;2000 as President of the Southern Africa Division of the Company. In January&nbsp;2000, Mr. Knauss was named President and Chief Executive Officer of The Minute Maid Company, formerly
a division of the Company, and became President of the Retail Division of Coca-Cola North America in January&nbsp;2003. He was appointed to his current position on February&nbsp;25, 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>Mary E. Minnick, </I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>44, is Executive Vice President of the Company and President and Chief Operating Officer, Asia. Ms.&nbsp;Minnick joined
the Company in 1983 and spent ten years working in Fountain Sales and the Bottle/Can Division of Coca-Cola USA. In 1993, she joined Corporate Marketing. In 1996, she was appointed Vice
President and Director, Middle and Far East Marketing, and served in that capacity until 1997 when she was appointed President of the South Pacific Division. In 2000, she was named President of
Coca-Cola (Japan) Company, Limited. Ms.&nbsp;Minnick was appointed President and Chief Operating Officer of the Asia strategic business unit as of January&nbsp;1, 2002, and was elected
to her current position in February&nbsp;2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>Daniel P. Palumbo, </I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>46, is Senior Vice President and Chief Marketing Officer of the Company. Mr.&nbsp;Palumbo joined the Company in
June&nbsp;2003 as Chief Marketing Officer. In July&nbsp;2003 he was elected Senior Vice President of the Company. Prior to joining the Company, Mr.&nbsp;Palumbo served six years with the Eastman
Kodak Company, concluding his service there as Senior Vice President of the Eastman Kodak Company and President of the Consumer Imaging Division, the photographic unit that accounts for half of the
company's sales. Prior to assuming the presidency of this Division, Mr.&nbsp;Palumbo served as the Division's Chief Marketing Officer. Prior to joining the Eastman Kodak Company, Mr.&nbsp;Palumbo
was with The Procter&nbsp;&amp; Gamble Company for 13&nbsp;years, where he held a number of domestic and international brand management assignments. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>Deval L. Patrick, </I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>47, is Executive Vice President, General Counsel and Secretary of the Company. He was elected to the first two positions
in April&nbsp;2001 and was elected Secretary of the Company in October&nbsp;2002, effective January&nbsp;1, 2003. Mr.&nbsp;Patrick was Assistant Attorney General of the United States and Chief
of the U.S. Justice Department's Civil Rights Division from 1994 until 1997, where he was responsible for enforcing federal laws prohibiting discrimination. From 1997 to 1999, Mr.&nbsp;Patrick was a
partner with the Boston law firm of Day Berry&nbsp;&amp; Howard LLP. Mr.&nbsp;Patrick joined the Company from Texaco&nbsp;Inc., where he served as Vice President and General Counsel from 1999 to
2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>Jos&eacute; Octavio Reyes, </I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>51, is Executive Vice President of the Company and President and Chief Operating Officer, Latin
America. He began his career with The Coca-Cola Company in 1980 in Coca-Cola de M&eacute;xico as Manager of Strategic Planning. In 1986 he was Manager of the Sprite and
diet Coke brands at Corporate </FONT></P>

</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>17</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=19,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=455056,FOLIO='17',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]DF1030A.;17',USER='JLAWRENA',CD='26-FEB-2004;17:40' -->
<A NAME="page_df1030_1_18"> </A>
<UL>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Headquarters.
In 1990, he was appointed Marketing Director for the Brazil Division, and later became Marketing and Operations Vice President for the Mexico Division. Mr.&nbsp;Reyes assumed the role
of Deputy Division President for the Mexico Division in January&nbsp;1996 and was named Division President for the Mexico Division in May&nbsp;1996. In 2000, Venezuela, Colombia, Central America
and the Caribbean were incorporated into the Division. Mr.&nbsp;Reyes assumed his position as President and Chief Operating Officer, Latin America in December&nbsp;2002, and was elected to his
current position in February&nbsp;2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>Danny L. Strickland, </I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>55, is Senior Vice President and Chief Innovation/Research and Development Officer of the Company.
Mr.&nbsp;Strickland joined the Company in April&nbsp;2003 and was elected Senior Vice President in June&nbsp;2003. Prior to joining the Company, Mr.&nbsp;Strickland served as Senior Vice
President, Innovation, Technology&nbsp;&amp; Quality at General Mills,&nbsp;Inc. from January&nbsp;1997 until March&nbsp;2003. There he was responsible for building a strong product pipeline,
innovation culture and organization. Prior to General Mills, Mr.&nbsp;Strickland held several research and development, innovation, engineering, quality and strategy roles in the United States and
abroad with Johnson&nbsp;&amp; Johnson from March&nbsp;1993 until December&nbsp;1996, Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc. from February&nbsp;1988 until March&nbsp;1993, and The Procter&nbsp;&amp; Gamble
Company from June&nbsp;1970 until February&nbsp;1988. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>Clyde C. Tuggle, </I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>41, is Senior Vice President, Worldwide Public Affairs and Communications, of the Company. Mr.&nbsp;Tuggle joined the
Company in 1989 in Corporate Issues Communications. From 1992 to 1998, he served as executive assistant to then Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Roberto C. Goizueta, managing business activities,
external affairs, and communications related to the Office of the Chairman. In 1998, he transferred to the Central European Division, where he held a variety of positions, including
director of Operations Development, deputy to the division president, and Austria region manager. In 2000, Mr.&nbsp;Tuggle returned to Atlanta as executive assistant to Chairman and Chief Executive
Officer Doug Daft and was elected Vice President. He was appointed Director of Worldwide Public Affairs and Communications in 2001. In 2002, he took on additional responsibilities, including
Government Affairs, North American Public Relations&nbsp;&amp; Communications, Strategic Event Services and Company Archives. Mr.&nbsp;Tuggle was elected to his current position in
February&nbsp;2003. </FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;All
executive officers serve at the pleasure of the Board of Directors. There is no family relationship between any of the executive officers of the Company. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>18</FONT></P>

<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>PART II    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dg1030_item_5._market_for_the_registr__ite04822"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dg1030_2"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>ITEM 5. MARKET FOR THE REGISTRANT'S COMMON EQUITY, RELATED STOCKHOLDER MATTERS AND ISSUER PURCHASES OF EQUITY SECURITIES    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the United States, the Company's common stock is listed and traded on the New York Stock Exchange (the principal market for our common stock) as well as the
Boston, Chicago, National, Pacific and Philadelphia stock exchanges. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following table sets forth, for the calendar periods indicated, the high and low closing prices per share for the Company's common stock, as reported on the New York Stock Exchange
composite tape, and dividend per share information: </FONT></P>

information under the heading "Equity Compensation Plan Information" in the Company's definitive Proxy Statement for the Annual Meeting of Share Owners to be held April&nbsp;21,

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>21</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=23,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=691655,FOLIO='21',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]DI1030B.;34',USER='SMENEZE',CD='26-FEB-2004;14:27' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_dk1030_1_22"> </A> </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dk1030_item_7._management_s_discussio__ite03668"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dk1030_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>ITEM 7. MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION <BR>  AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><U>Overview</U>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following Management's Discussion and Analysis ("MD&amp;A") is intended to help the reader understand The Coca-Cola Company. MD&amp;A is provided as a
supplement to&#151;and should be read in conjunction with&#151;our financial statements and the accompanying notes ("Notes"). This overview provides our perspective on the individual
sections of MD&amp;A, as well as a few helpful hints for reading these pages. MD&amp;A includes the following sections: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Our Business &#151; </I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>a general description of our business; the value drivers of our business; measurements; and
opportunities, challenges and risks.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Financial Strategies and Risk Management</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> &#151; information about debt financing, share repurchases, dividend policy
and financial risk management.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Application of Critical Accounting Policies</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> &#151; a discussion of accounting policies that require critical judgments
and estimates.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Operations Review</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> &#151; an analysis of our Company's consolidated results of operations for the three years presented
in our financial statements. Our Company operates in one business&nbsp;&#150; nonalcoholic beverages. Except to the extent that differences between our five geographic operating segments are
material to an understanding of our business as a whole, we present the discussion in this MD&amp;A on a consolidated&nbsp;basis.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Liquidity, Capital Resources and Financial Position</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> &#151; an analysis of cash flows, sources and uses of cash,
contractual obligations, and financial position.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Forward-Looking Statements &#151; </I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>cautionary information about forward-looking statements and a description of certain
risks and uncertainties that could cause our actual results to differ materially from the Company's historical results or our current expectations or projections. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><U>Our Business</U>  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> <U>General</U>  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We are the world's largest beverage company, with four of the world's top five soft-drink brands&#151;Coca-Cola, Diet Coke, Fanta
and Sprite. Because we believe in offering choices, we provide a wide variety of nonalcoholic beverages to meet consumers' desires and needs. Our Company owns or licenses nearly 400 trademarked
brands&#151;including carbonated soft drinks, juices and juice drinks, sports drinks, water products, teas, coffees and other beverages. Finished beverage products bearing our trademarks are
sold in more than 200&nbsp;countries. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
Company generates revenues, income and cash flows by manufacturing and selling beverage concentrates and syrups as well as some finished beverages. We generally sell these products
to bottling and canning operations, distributors, fountain wholesalers and some fountain retailers. We authorize our bottling partners to manufacture and package products made from our concentrates
and syrups into branded finished products, that they then distribute and sell. Bottling partners, in which our Company has no ownership interest or a noncontrolling ownership interest, produced and
distributed 82&nbsp;percent of our 2003 worldwide unit case&nbsp;volume. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
make significant marketing expenditures in support of our brands, including advertising costs, sponsorship fees and special promotional events. Retailers and distributors receive
rebates, promotions and point-of-sale displays. Our bottling partners receive advertising support and funds designated for cold-drink equipment. Consumers receive
coupons, discounts and promotional incentives. These marketing expenditures </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>22</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=24,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=513213,FOLIO='22',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]DK1030A.;32',USER='SSTANSE',CD='25-FEB-2004;21:07' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1030_1_23"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>help
to enhance awareness of and increase consumer preference for our brands. Greater awareness and preference promotes long-term growth in profitable volume, per capita consumption and
our share of worldwide nonalcoholic beverage sales. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
Company articulates its mission as a promise: </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Our Company exists to benefit and refresh everyone it touches</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. More specifically,
through our actions we strive every day to provide quality in the marketplace, enrich the workplace, preserve the environment and strengthen our communities. Building upon the foundation of our
promise, we focus on the six strategic priorities discussed in Item 1 of this report. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> <U>Value Drivers of Our Business</U>  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We believe that executing our six strategic priorities creates value. Consistent with a commitment to effective execution, our Company focuses on three key value
drivers: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>profitable
growth;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>cost
management; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>efficient
capital structure. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Profitable Growth.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We believe healthy brands&#151;properly supported by marketing and
innovation, leveraged across markets and targeted to a broad consumer base&#151;drive profitable growth. Our Company continues to broaden our family of brands. In particular, we are expanding
and growing our noncarbonated offerings to provide more alternatives to consumers. With this expansion and growth, our Company is focused on maintaining or increasing profit margins. We further intend
to focus on improving
margins in faster growing but lower-margin countries. To manage this expansion and growth, we are shifting from a volume focus to a "volume and value" focus. The added emphasis on value focuses on
gross profit and profit before taxes. To support this shift, beginning in 2003 our compensation incentives emphasize gross profit, profit before income taxes and net income instead of unit case
volume. We believe that tailored brand, package, price and channel strategies help achieve profitable growth. We are implementing these strategies and accelerating profitable growth through close
alignment with our bottling partners. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cost Management.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A principal focus of cost management will continue to be on supply chain
initiatives. Over the past year in North America, Japan and China, the Coca-Cola System established supply chain management companies to help increase procurement efficiencies and to
centralize production and logistics operations. Lowering supply chain costs improves system economics. Alignment with all bottlers, including ways to achieve additional joint savings, represents a
critical area of focus. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cost
reduction is another key initiative. One key area of focus, for example, is to decrease over time general and administrative costs as a percentage of net operating revenues. In
2003, we took steps to streamline and simplify our operations. Refer to Note&nbsp;17. As a result of these streamlining initiatives, apart from the charge to 2003 earnings of $561&nbsp;million, we
estimate that the Company's financial results benefited by approximately $50&nbsp;million (pretax) in 2003 and will benefit by at least $100&nbsp;million (pretax) on an annualized basis beginning
in&nbsp;2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Efficient Capital Structure.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our capital structure is intended to optimize our cost of capital. We
believe our strong capital position, our access to key financial markets, our ability to raise funds at a low effective cost and our overall low cost of borrowing provide a competitive advantage. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
our cash flows increase, we expect to increase our share repurchases. Furthermore, dividends increased for the 42nd straight year in 2004, and we believe that for the foreseeable
future, our Board of Directors intends to increase our dividends. Refer to MD&amp;A heading "Financial Strategies and Risk Management." </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>23</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=25,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=119346,FOLIO='23',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]DK1030A.;32',USER='SSTANSE',CD='25-FEB-2004;21:07' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1030_1_24"> </A>
<BR>
<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> <U>Measurements</U>  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We believe these value drivers, when properly implemented, will result in: (1)&nbsp;maintaining or improving our gross profit margin; (2)&nbsp;providing
additional leverage over time through reduced expenses as a percentage of net operating revenues; and (3)&nbsp;optimizing our cost of capital. The ultimate measure of our success will be reflected
in the items below. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Results of Operations.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net operating revenues, gross profit, operating income, income before income
taxes and net income per share represent key measurements of these value drivers. In 2003, net operating revenues totaled approximately $21.0&nbsp;billion, an 8&nbsp;percent increase from 2002.
Gross profit totaled $13.3&nbsp;billion in 2003, a 7&nbsp;percent increase from 2002. Operating income was approximately $5.2&nbsp;billion, a 4&nbsp;percent decrease from 2002. This amount
included a charge of $573&nbsp;million primarily related to streamlining initiatives. Income before income taxes was approximately $5.5&nbsp;billion, virtually the same as 2002. Net income per
share (basic and diluted) was $1.77. These measurements will continue to be a key management focus in 2004 and beyond. Refer to MD&amp;A heading "Operations Review." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Liquidity and Capital Resources.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2003, our net cash provided by operating activities was
approximately $5.5&nbsp;billion, a 15&nbsp;percent increase from 2002. For years 2004 through 2008, we expect our cumulative net cash provided by operating activities to be in excess of
$32&nbsp;billion. We believe this demonstrates one of our Company's strengths&#151;the ability to generate significant cash flows to reinvest in our business. We utilize the cash in ways that
management believes provides the greatest value. Principal uses of our cash flows are: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Share repurchases</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. In 2003, share repurchases were approximately $1.5&nbsp;billion, and we expect 2004 share repurchases to
be at least $2&nbsp;billion.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Dividends</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. In 2003, dividends were approximately $2.2&nbsp;billion, and we increased dividends in 2004.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Capital expenditures</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>.</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> These totaled $812&nbsp;million in 2003, and we expect 2004 capital
expenditures to be less than $1&nbsp;billion. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Refer
to MD&amp;A heading "Liquidity, Capital Resources and Financial Condition." </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> <U>Opportunities, Challenges and Risks</U>  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating in more than 200 countries provides unique opportunities for our Company. Challenges and risks accompany these opportunities. Our Company's promise, six
strategic priorities and the value drivers of our business provide the foundation for our response to the opportunities, challenges and risks before us. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Looking
forward, management has identified certain challenges and risks that demand the attention of the beverage industry and our Company. Of these, three key challenges and risks are
discussed below. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Obesity and Inactive Lifestyles.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Increasing consumer and regulatory awareness of the health problems
arising from obesity and inactive lifestyles represents a serious risk. We recognize that obesity is a complex and serious public health problem. Our commitment to consumers begins with our broad
product line, led by Coca-Cola and a wide selection of diet and light beverages, juices and juice drinks, sports drinks and waters. Our commitment also includes adhering to the right
policies in schools and in the marketplace; supporting programs to encourage physical activity and to promote nutrition education; and continuously meeting changing consumer needs through beverage
innovation, choice and variety. We are committed to playing an appropriate role in helping to address this issue in cooperation with governments, educators and consumers through science-based
solutions and programs. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Water Quality and Quantity.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Water represents another issue that will increasingly require our
Company's attention and collaboration with the beverage industry. Water is the main ingredient in every product our industry offers. It is also a limited resource facing unprecedented challenges from
over-exploitation, increasing pollution and poor management. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>24</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=26,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=390133,FOLIO='24',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]DK1030A.;32',USER='SSTANSE',CD='25-FEB-2004;21:07' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1030_1_25"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
Company and the beverage industry are in an excellent position to share the water expertise we have developed in the communities we serve&#151;in resource management,
wastewater treatment, rainwater harvesting and even desalination. As demand for water continues to increase around the world, we expect cooperation will be critical. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Free Trade.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We believe the benefits of free trade&#151;comparative advantage, price
competition, labor mobility and ultimately prosperity and economic growth over the long term&#151;are clear. However, the breakdown of trade talks, public pressure against trade organizations
and the selective increase in tariffs around the world demonstrate the challenges related to free trade. It is important for our Company in particular and the beverage industry in general to show
leadership in communicating the benefits of free trade. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;All
three of these challenges and risks&#151;obesity, water and free trade&#151;have the </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>potential</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> to adversely affect our
industry. We expect to work at the industry level to address these matters, and we believe our Company is well positioned to have a positive impact related to these challenges and risks. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition to the three key challenges and risks impacting our industry as discussed above, we have identified other challenges and risks that could impact the Company's future
financial results including the&nbsp;following: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>maintenance
of brand image and product quality;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>profitable
expansion and growth of our family of brands in the competitive marketplace. Refer to MD&amp;A heading "Profitable Growth."
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>restrictions
on imports and exports and sources of supply; duties or tariffs; and changes in governmental regulations;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>the
imposition of additional restrictions on currency conversion and remittances abroad; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>policy
concerns particular to the United States with respect to a country in which the Company has operations. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>We
believe many opportunities accompany these challenges and risks. Among these opportunities, we believe the following opportunities exist for our Company. </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>growth
potential for all nonalcoholic beverage categories&#151;carbonated soft drinks, waters, juices and juice drinks, teas, coffees and sports drinks;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>new
product introductions, intended to contribute to higher gross profits;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>premium
packages, intended to generate strong revenue growth;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>significant
package, pricing and channel opportunities to maximize profitable growth, especially in North America, Japan and other key markets; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>proper
positioning to capture industry growth&#151;we believe more than 80&nbsp;percent of worldwide incremental industry growth through 2007 will be from locations
outside the United States. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Looking
back at 2003, we identified several events noted below that negatively impacted our Company. These events impacted seven countries directly (and other countries indirectly) on
five continents, highlighting the risks of operating globally. Despite these 2003 challenges and risks, our Company posted net operating revenues and net income growth. Processes that allow us to
anticipate crises (where possible) and respond quickly to challenges and risks are critical to our success. </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>production
shutdown of the Company's products in Venezuela for approximately one-half of the first quarter of 2003 due to a national general strike and political
turmoil;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>disruption
caused by the implementation of a German deposit law on nonreturnable packages; </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>25</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=27,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=154920,FOLIO='25',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]DK1030A.;32',USER='SSTANSE',CD='25-FEB-2004;21:07' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1030_1_26"> </A>
<UL>
<UL>
</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>the
war in Iraq and continued overall political unrest in the Middle East;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>poor
weather conditions in Japan and parts of North America;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>fewer
consumers in North American restaurants, hotels and leisure channels;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>outbreak

<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>accusations,
which we believe to be false, that our soft drinks in India contain high levels of pesticides. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><U>Financial Strategies and Risk Management</U>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following strategies are intended to optimize our cost of capital. We consider these strategies to be of critical importance in pursuing our goal of
maximizing share-owner value. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> <U>Debt Financing</U>  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our Company maintains debt levels we consider prudent based on our cash flow, interest coverage and percentage of debt to capital. We use debt financing to lower
our overall cost of capital, which increases our return on share-owners' equity. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of December&nbsp;31, 2003, our long-term debt was rated "A+" by Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor's and "Aa3" by Moody's, and our commercial paper program was rated
"A-1" and "P-1" by Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor's and Moody's, respectively. In assessing our credit strength, both Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor's and Moody's consider our capital
structure and financial policies as well as aggregated balance sheet and other financial information for the Company and certain bottlers including Coca-Cola Enterprises&nbsp;Inc.
("CCE") and Coca-Cola Hellenic Bottling Company S.A. ("CCHBC"). While the Company has no legal obligation for the debt of these bottlers, the rating agencies believe the strategic
importance of the bottlers to the Company's business model provides the Company with an incentive to keep these bottlers viable. If our credit ratings were reduced by the rating agencies, our interest
expense could increase. Additionally, if certain bottlers' credit ratings were to decline, the Company's share of equity income could be reduced as a result of the potential increase in interest
expense for these bottlers. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
rating agencies monitor our interest coverage ratio. Generally, this ratio is computed as income before taxes plus interest expense, divided by the sum of interest expense and
capitalized interest. The interest coverage ratio was 32x, 28x and 20x, respectively, for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2003, 2002 and 2001.
Rating agencies often exclude unusual items from the calculation; however, we calculated the ratios based on our reported&nbsp;results. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
monitor our interest coverage ratio and, as previously indicated, the rating agencies consider our ratio in assessing our credit ratings. However, as described above, the rating
agencies aggregate financial data for certain bottlers with our Company when assessing our debt rating. As such, the key measure is the aggregate interest coverage ratio of the Company and certain
bottlers. Both Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor's and Moody's employ different aggregation methodologies and have different thresholds for the aggregate interest coverage ratio. These thresholds are not
necessarily permanent nor are they fully disclosed to our Company. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
global presence and strong capital position give us access to key financial markets around the world, enabling us to raise funds with a low effective cost. This posture, coupled with
active management of our mix of short-term and long-term debt, results in a lower overall cost of borrowing. Our debt management policies, in conjunction with our share
repurchase programs and investment activity, can result in current liabilities exceeding current assets. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>26</FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our Company monitors the financial measures discussed above in conjunction with our mix of fixed-rate and variable-rate
debt and other business and financial risks. The above financial measures trended positively in 2003 and 2002, reflecting improved business results and effective capital management strategies. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> <U>Share Repurchases</U>  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

table below presents shares repurchased and average price per share under the 1996 plan: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Since the inception of our initial share repurchase program in 1984 through our current program as of December&nbsp;31, 2003, we have purchased
more than 1&nbsp;billion shares of our Company's common stock. This represents 33&nbsp;percent of the shares outstanding as of January&nbsp;1, 1984 at an average price per share of $14.07. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
expect to repurchase at least $2&nbsp;billion of the Company's common shares in 2004. Because we expect our operating cash flows to increase in subsequent years, we also expect to
increase repurchases of the Company's common shares in subsequent years. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> <U>Dividend Policy</U>  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At its February&nbsp;2004 meeting, our Board of Directors again increased our quarterly dividend by approximately 14 percent, raising it to $0.25 per share,
equivalent to a full-year dividend of $1.00 per share in 2004. This is our 42<SUP>nd</SUP> consecutive annual increase. Our annual common stock dividend was $0.88 per share, $0.80 per
share and $0.72 per share in 2003, 2002 and 2001, respectively. The 2003 dividend
represents a 10&nbsp;percent increase from 2002, and the 2002 dividend compared to 2001 represents an 11&nbsp;percent increase. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> <U>Financial Risk Management</U>  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our Company uses derivative financial instruments primarily to reduce our exposure to adverse fluctuations in interest rates and foreign exchange rates and, to a
lesser extent, adverse fluctuations in commodity prices and other market risks. We do not enter into derivative financial instruments for trading purposes. As a matter of policy, all our derivative
positions are used to reduce risk by hedging an underlying economic exposure. Because of the high correlation between the hedging instrument and the underlying exposure, fluctuations in the value of
the instruments are generally offset by reciprocal changes in the value of the underlying exposure. Virtually all of our derivatives are straightforward, over-the-counter
instruments with liquid markets. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Foreign Currency.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We manage most of our foreign currency exposures on a consolidated basis, which
allows us to net certain exposures and take advantage of any natural offsets. Our five geographic operating segments generated approximately 81&nbsp;percent of 2003 operating income outside the
United States; therefore, weakness in one particular currency is often offset by strengths in others over time. We use derivative financial instruments to further reduce our net exposure to currency
fluctuations. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>27</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=29,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=155853,FOLIO='27',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]DL1030A.;34',USER='NLUCCA',CD='26-FEB-2004;15:05' -->
<A NAME="page_dl1030_1_28"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
Company enters into forward exchange contracts and purchases currency options (principally euro and Japanese yen) and collars to hedge certain portions of forecasted cash flows
denominated in foreign currencies. Additionally, we enter into forward exchange contracts to offset the earnings impact relating to exchange rate fluctuations on certain monetary assets and
liabilities. We also enter into forward exchange contracts as hedges of net investments in international operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest Rates.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We monitor our mix of fixed-rate and variable-rate debt, as
well as our mix of term debt versus nonterm debt. This monitoring includes a review of business and other financial risks as noted above. We also enter into interest rate swap agreements to manage
these risks. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Value at Risk.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We monitor our exposure to financial market risks using several objective measurement
systems, including value-at-risk models. Our value-at-risk calculations use a historical simulation model to estimate potential future losses in the
fair value of our derivatives and other financial instruments that could occur as a result of adverse movements in foreign currency and interest rates. We have not considered the potential impact of
favorable movements in foreign
currency and interest rates on our calculations. We examined historical weekly returns over the previous 10&nbsp;years to calculate our value at risk. The average value at risk represents the simple
average of quarterly amounts over the past year. As a result of our foreign currency value-at-risk calculations, we estimate with 95&nbsp;percent confidence that the fair
values of our foreign currency derivatives and other financial instruments, over a one-week period, would decline by less than $26&nbsp;million, $34&nbsp;million and
$43&nbsp;million, respectively, using 2003, 2002 or 2001 average fair values and by less than $28&nbsp;million and $31&nbsp;million, respectively, using December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002 fair
values. According to our interest rate value-at-risk calculations, we estimate with 95&nbsp;percent confidence that any increase in our net interest expense due to an adverse
move in our 2003 average or in our December&nbsp;31, 2003 interest rates over a one-week period would not have a material impact on our financial statements. Our December&nbsp;31, 2002
and 2001 estimates also were not material to our financial statements. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><U>Application of Critical Accounting Policies</U>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management discussed with our Audit Committee the development, selection and disclosure of our critical accounting policies and estimates and the application of
these policies and estimates. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> <U>Basis of Presentation and Consolidation</U>  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our consolidated financial statements are prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States. Our Company consolidates all
entities that we control by ownership of a majority voting interest. Refer to Note&nbsp;1 for a discussion of variable interest entities. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
use the equity method to account for our investments for which we have the ability to exercise significant influence over operating and financial policies. Our consolidated net income
includes our Company's share of the net earnings of these companies. The difference between consolidation and the equity method impacts certain financial ratios because of the presentation of the
detailed line items reported in the financial statements. However, our consolidated net income for the period and our share-owners' equity at the end of the period are the same whether the investment
in the company is accounted for under the equity method or the company is consolidated. Our judgments regarding the level of influence of each equity method investment include considering key factors
such as our ownership interest, representation on the board of directors, participation in policy-making decisions and material intercompany transactions. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
use the cost method to account for our investments in companies that we do not control and for which we do not have the ability to exercise significant influence over operating and
financial policies. In accordance with the cost method, these investments are recorded at cost or fair value, as appropriate. We record dividend income when applicable dividends are declared. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>28</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=30,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=799764,FOLIO='28',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]DL1030A.;34',USER='NLUCCA',CD='26-FEB-2004;15:05' -->
<A NAME="page_dl1030_1_29"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
Company eliminates from our financial results all significant intercompany transactions, including the intercompany portion of transactions with equity method investees. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective
February&nbsp;2002, our Company acquired control of Coca-Cola Erfrischungsgetraenke AG ("CCEAG"), the largest bottler of the Company's beverage products in
Germany. Under our policy, we concluded that CCEAG should be consolidated in our financial statements based on the following. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Prior
to February&nbsp;2002, our Company accounted for CCEAG under the equity method of accounting. Our Company had an approximate 41&nbsp;percent ownership interest in the
outstanding shares of CCEAG. In February&nbsp;2002, in accordance with the terms of the Control and Profit and Loss Transfer Agreement ("CPL"), our Company obtained control of CCEAG
for a period of up to five years. Furthermore, we also entered into a Pooling Agreement with certain share owners of CCEAG that provided our Company with voting control of CCEAG. In return for control
of CCEAG, the Company guaranteed annual payments, in lieu of dividends by CCEAG, to all other CCEAG share owners. Additionally, all other CCEAG share owners entered into either a put or a put/call
option agreement with the Company, exercisable at any time up to the December&nbsp;31, 2006 expiration date. Our Company entered into either put or put/call agreements for shares representing an
approximate 59&nbsp;percent interest in CCEAG. The spread in the strike prices of the put and call options is only approximately 3&nbsp;percent. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Because
the terms of the CPL transferred control and all the economic risks and rewards of CCEAG to the Company immediately, we determined consolidation was appropriate. Refer to
Note&nbsp;18. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
December&nbsp;2003, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ("FASB") issued FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;46 (revised December&nbsp;2003) ("Interpretation 46"), "Consolidation
of Variable Interest Entities." We do not anticipate that Interpretation 46 will have a material impact on our basis of presentation and consolidation. Refer to Note&nbsp;1. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> <U>Recoverability of Noncurrent Assets</U>  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management's assessment of the recoverability of noncurrent assets involves critical accounting estimates. The assessments reflect management's best assumptions
and estimates. Factors that management must estimate when performing impairment tests include, among other items, sales volume, prices, inflation, discount rates, marketing spending, exchange rates,
tax rates and capital spending. These factors are interdependent and therefore do not change in isolation. Significant management judgment is involved in estimating these factors, and they include
inherent uncertainties; however, the assumptions we use are consistent with our internal planning. Management periodically evaluates and updates the estimates based on the conditions that influence
these factors. The variability of these factors depends on a number of conditions, including uncertainty about future events, and thus our accounting estimates may change from period to period. If
other assumptions and estimates had been used in the current period, the balances for noncurrent assets could have been materially impacted. Furthermore, if management uses different assumptions or if
different conditions occur in future periods, future operating results could be materially impacted. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
in more than 200 countries subjects our Company to many uncertainties and risks related to various economic, political and regulatory environments. Refer to MD&amp;A heading "Our
Business&#151;Opportunities, Challenges and Risks." As a result, many assumptions must be made by management when determining the recoverability of noncurrent assets. An example of one
uncertainty relates to the deposit law on certain nonreturnable beverage packages enacted by the German government in the first quarter of 2003. The change in law on January&nbsp;1, 2003 and
subsequent developments resulted in most retailers delisting nonreturnable packages. After an initial decrease in volume growth, our management acted quickly to address this matter and, as a result,
our business posted sequential quarterly improvements. The new deposit law has created a difficult environment for the industry, but we believe our management successfully positioned our Company to
respond to German consumers' increasing preference for returnable packaging. However, if other unexpected political matters or abrupt market shifts occur that impact our industry or our Company,
certain </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>29</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=31,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=420769,FOLIO='29',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]DL1030A.;34',USER='NLUCCA',CD='26-FEB-2004;15:05' -->
<A NAME="page_dl1030_1_30"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>assets
in Germany may be at risk for impairment. We proactively managed and will continue to manage our investments in new returnable lines and related bottling infrastructure to minimize our exposure
as the ongoing regulatory changes develop. We will continue to monitor this situation. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
the following noncurrent assets, we perform tests of impairment, as appropriate. For the applicable assets, we perform tests when certain conditions exist that may indicate the
carrying value may not be recoverable. For other applicable assets, we perform tests at least annually or more frequently if events or circumstances indicate that an asset may be impaired: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Many of the noncurrent assets listed above are located in markets that we consider to be developing or to have changing political environments.
These markets include Germany, where the future of the nonreturnable deposit law creates uncertainty; the Middle East, where political and civil unrest continues; and certain markets in Latin America,
Asia and Africa where local economic and political conditions are unstable. In many of these markets, the Company has bottling assets and investments. The list below reflects
the Company's carrying value of noncurrent assets in these markets. By nature, these assets involve inherent risks not relevant to assets located in developed or stable markets. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>30</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=32,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=795182,FOLIO='30',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]DL1030A.;34',USER='NLUCCA',CD='26-FEB-2004;15:05' -->
<A NAME="page_dl1030_1_31"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Equity Method and Cost Method Investments.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For most publicly traded investments, the
fair value of our Company's investment is often readily available based on quoted market prices. For non&#150;publicly traded investments, management's assessment of fair value is based on
valuation methodologies including discounted cash flows, estimates of sales proceeds and external appraisals, as appropriate. The ability to accurately predict future cash flows, especially in
developing and unstable markets, may impact the determination of fair value. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the event a decline in fair value of an investment occurs, management may be required to determine if the decline in market value is other than temporary. Management's assessments as
to the nature of a decline in fair value are based on the valuation methodologies discussed above and our ability and intent to hold the investment. We consider our equity method investees to be
strategic long-term investments; therefore, we generally complete our assessments with a long-term viewpoint. If the fair value is less than the carrying value and the decline
in value is considered to be other than temporary, an appropriate write-down is recorded. Management's assessments of fair value in accordance with these valuation methodologies represent
our best estimates as of the time of the impairment review and are consistent with our internal planning. If different fair values were estimated, this could have a material impact on the financial
statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following table presents the difference between calculated fair values, based on quoted closing prices of publicly traded shares, and our Company's carrying values for significant
publicly traded bottlers accounted for as equity method investees (in millions): </FONT></P>

<TD WIDTH="11%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>$&nbsp;&nbsp;8,094</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="11%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>$&nbsp;&nbsp;4,056</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="10%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><B>$&nbsp;&nbsp;4,038</B></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=7><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE></DIV>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"><TABLE WIDTH="85%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2><SUP>1</SUP></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="98%"><FONT SIZE=2>In instances where carrying value exceeds fair value, the current decline in value is considered to be temporary.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE></DIV>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other Assets.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our Company invests in infrastructure programs with our bottlers that
are directed at strengthening our bottling system and increasing unit case volume. Additionally, our Company advances payments to certain customers to fund future marketing activities intended to
generate profitable volume and expenses such payments over the applicable period. Advance payments are also made to certain customers for distribution rights. Payments under these programs are
generally capitalized as other assets in our balance sheets. Management periodically evaluates the recoverability of these assets by preparing estimates of sales volume, the resulting gross profit,
cash flows and other factors. If the assets are assessed to be recoverable, they are amortized over the periods benefited. If the carrying value of these assets is considered to be not recoverable,
such assets are written down as appropriate. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Property, Plant and Equipment.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Certain events or changes in circumstances may indicate that the
recoverability of the carrying amount of property, plant and equipment should be assessed. Such events or changes may include a significant decrease in market value, a significant change in the
business climate in a particular market, or a current-period operating or cash flow loss combined with historical losses or projected future losses. If an event occurs or changes in circumstances are
present, we estimate the future cash flows expected to result from the use of the asset and its eventual disposition. If the sum of the expected future cash </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>31</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=33,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=750552,FOLIO='31',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]DL1030A.;34',USER='NLUCCA',CD='26-FEB-2004;15:05' -->
<A NAME="page_dl1030_1_32"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>flows
(undiscounted and without interest charges) is less than the carrying amount, we recognize an impairment loss. The impairment loss recognized is the amount by which the carrying amount exceeds
the fair value. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Goodwill, Trademarks and Other Intangible Assets.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Statement of Financial Accounting Standards
("SFAS") No.&nbsp;142, "Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets," classifies intangible assets into three categories: (1)&nbsp;intangible assets with definite lives subject to amortization;
(2)&nbsp;intangible assets with indefinite lives not subject to amortization; and (3)&nbsp;goodwill. For intangible assets with definite lives, tests for impairment must be performed if conditions
exist that indicate the carrying value may not be recoverable. For intangible assets with indefinite lives and goodwill, tests for impairment must be performed at least annually. Such tests for
impairment are also required for intangible assets recorded by our equity method investees. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
trademarks and other intangible assets determined to have definite lives are amortized over their useful lives. In accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;142, if conditions exist that
indicate the carrying value may not be recoverable, we review such trademarks and other intangible assets with definite lives for impairment to ensure they are appropriately valued. Such conditions
may include an economic downturn in a market or a change in the assessment of future operations. Trademarks and other intangible assets determined to have an indefinite useful life are not amortized.
We test such trademarks and other intangible assets with indefinite useful lives for impairment annually or more frequently if events or circumstances indicate that assets might be impaired. Goodwill
is not amortized. We perform tests for impairment of goodwill annually or more frequently if events or circumstances indicate it might be impaired. Such tests include comparing the fair value of a
reporting unit with its carrying value, including goodwill. We use a variety of methodologies in conducting these impairment assessments, including cash flow analysis, estimates of sales proceeds and
independent appraisals. Where applicable, we use an appropriate discount rate, based on the Company's cost of capital rate or location-specific economic factors. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> <U>Income Taxes</U>  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our income tax expense and related balance sheet amounts involve significant management estimates and judgments. Judgments regarding realization of deferred tax
assets and the ultimate outcome of tax-related contingencies represent key items involved in the determination of income tax expense and related balance sheet&nbsp;accounts. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Deferred
tax assets represent items to be used as a tax deduction or credit in future tax returns for which we have already properly recorded the tax benefit in our income statement.
Realization of our deferred tax assets reflects our tax planning strategies. We establish valuation allowances for deferred tax assets that we do not believe will be realized. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Tax
assessments may arise several years after tax returns have been filed. Predicting the outcome of such tax assessments involves uncertainty; however, we believe that recorded tax
liabilities adequately account for our analysis of probable outcomes. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Refer
to Note&nbsp;15. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> <U>Contingencies</U>  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our Company is subject to various claims and contingencies related to legal proceedings. Refer to Note&nbsp;11. Due to their nature, such legal proceedings
involve inherent uncertainties including, but not limited to, court rulings, negotiations between affected parties and governmental actions. Management assesses the probability of loss for such
contingencies and accrues a liability and/or discloses the relevant circumstances, as appropriate. Management believes that any liability to the Company that may arise as a result of currently pending
legal proceedings will not have a material adverse effect on the financial condition of the Company taken as a whole. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>32</FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Refer to the above Analysis of Consolidated Statements of Income in condensed form while reading the operations review below. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>33</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=35,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=239428,FOLIO='33',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]DM1030A.;35',USER='NLUCCA',CD='26-FEB-2004;15:06' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1030_1_34"> </A>
<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> <U>Net Operating Revenues</U>  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net operating revenues increased by $1,480&nbsp;million in 2003 versus 2002. Net operating revenues increased by $2,019&nbsp;million in 2002 versus 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following table indicates, on a percentage basis, the estimated impact of key factors resulting in significant increases (decreases) in net operating revenues: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"><TABLE WIDTH="76%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>

<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>

<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="TOP">

<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The increase in gallon sales in 2003 included the favorable impact of the consolidation of full year results in 2003 for 2002 acquisitions. In the
second quarter of 2002, our Company entered into a long-term license agreement involving Seagram's mixers, a carbonated line of drinks. In the third quarter of 2002, our Company and Danone
Waters of North America ("DWNA") formed a new joint venture company, CCDA Waters, L.L.C. ("CCDA") for the production, marketing and distribution of DWNA's bottled spring and source water business in
the United States. We own a controlling 51&nbsp;percent interest in the joint venture company, with a license for the use of the Dannon and Sparkletts brands, as well as ownership of several value
brands. Also in the third quarter of 2002, we entered into a master distribution agreement for the Evian water brand in the United States and Canada. Gallons shipped in 2003 increased when compared to
2002 as a result of owning and operating these businesses throughout 2003 compared to only owning and operating them for a portion of 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;"Structural
changes" refer to acquisitions or dispositions of bottling or canning operations. Structural changes had a negative impact in 2003 due partially to the deconsolidation of
Cosmos Bottling Corporation ("CBC") during the second quarter of 2003. This negative impact was partially offset by the inclusion of one additional month of revenue from CCEAG. CCEAG was consolidated
in February&nbsp;2002; therefore, the 2002 period contained only 11&nbsp;months of CCEAG revenues versus the full year in 2003. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective
October&nbsp;1, 2003, the Company and all our bottling partners in Japan completed a structural change that created a nationally integrated supply chain management company to
centralize procurement, production and logistics operations for the entire Coca-Cola system in Japan. As a result of the creation of this supply chain management company in Japan, a
portion of our Company's business has essentially been converted from a finished product business model to a concentrate business model. This
shift of certain products to a concentrate business model resulted in a reduction of revenues and cost of goods sold, each in the same amount ($282&nbsp;million), thus having no impact on our
Company's gross profit or operating income. The formation of this entity included the sale of Company inventory and the leasing of certain Company assets to this new entity on October&nbsp;1, 2003,
as well as our recording of a liability for certain contractual obligations to Japanese bottlers. Such amounts were not material to the Company's results of operations. We expect that both net
operating revenues and cost of goods sold will be reduced by approximately $750&nbsp;million for the nine months ending September&nbsp;30, 2004 compared to the same period of 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
timing of acquisitions and structural changes does not occur consistently from period to period. As a result, anticipating the impact of such transactions on future increases or
decreases in net operating revenues (and other financial statement line items) usually is not possible. However, we expect to continue to sell bottling interests and buy bottling interests in limited
circumstances, and as a result, we will continue to have structural impacts to our financial statements in future periods. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
impact of the weaker U.S. dollar in 2003 was driven primarily by the stronger euro that favorably impacted the Europe, Eurasia and Middle East operating segment and the stronger yen
that favorably impacted </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>34</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=36,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=755871,FOLIO='34',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]DM1030A.;35',USER='NLUCCA',CD='26-FEB-2004;15:06' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1030_1_35"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>the
Asia operating segment. This impact was partially offset by generally weaker currencies negatively impacting our Latin America operating segment. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
acquisitions of our interests in Odwalla,&nbsp;Inc. ("Odwalla"), the CCDA water brands and CBC (structural change) contributed significantly to the increased 2002 net operating
revenues. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
most significant structural change in 2002 was the consolidation of CCEAG. This consolidation was partially offset by the sale and resulting deconsolidation of our Russian and
Baltics bottling operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
combined 2002 net operating revenues resulting from the structural change of CCEAG and the acquisitions of our interests in Odwalla, CCDA and CBC were approximately
$1.5&nbsp;billion. The Russian and Baltics bottling operations accounted for approximately $150&nbsp;million of 2001 net operating revenues. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Price
increases and product/geographic mix in selected countries positively impacted our 2002 net operating revenues. The improvements in these core business factors reflected a positive
trend in 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
strength of the U.S. dollar in 2002 relative to most major currencies had a negative impact on net operating revenues. The stronger U.S. dollar compared to the Japanese yen, the
Argentine peso, the Mexican peso, the Brazilian real, the Venezuelan bolivar and the South African rand was partially offset by strength in the euro. Refer to MD&amp;A heading "Exchange." </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Information
about our net operating revenues by operating segment on a percentage basis is as follows: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The net operating revenues for Europe, Eurasia and Middle East significantly increased in 2003 due to sound business fundamentals, innovation,
strong marketing strategies, rigorous cost management, positive currency trends and favorable weather during the summer months. The 2002 net operating revenues for Europe, Eurasia and Middle East
increased primarily due to the consolidation of CCEAG. Net operating revenues in 2002 for Latin America were negatively impacted by exchange fluctuations and challenging economic conditions, primarily
in Argentina, Venezuela and Brazil. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> <U>Gross Profit</U>  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The decrease in 2003 gross profit margin versus 2002 was primarily the result of the inclusion of higher-revenue, lower-margin CCEAG, CCDA and Evian results for
the full year of 2003. These results were partially offset by the creation of the nationally integrated supply chain company in Japan (previously discussed under MD&amp;A heading "Net Operating
Revenues"), the deconsolidation of CBC during the second quarter of 2003 and the receipt during the first quarter of 2003 of a settlement of approximately $52&nbsp;million from certain defendants in
a vitamin antitrust litigation. Refer to Note&nbsp;16. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
currently estimate that the creation of the nationally integrated supply chain company in Japan, partially offset by other structural changes such as consolidation of entities in
accordance with Interpretation 46, will improve the gross profit margin in 2004 compared to 2003. Refer to Note&nbsp;1 for a discussion of Interpretation 46. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>35</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=37,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=825613,FOLIO='35',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]DM1030A.;35',USER='NLUCCA',CD='26-FEB-2004;15:06' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1030_1_36"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
cost of goods sold increased in 2002 compared to 2001 primarily as a result of the acquisitions of our interests in Odwalla, the CCDA water brands and CBC and the structural change
of CCEAG. Total combined 2002 cost of goods sold for these entities was $844&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
decrease in 2002 gross profit margin was due primarily to the consolidation of lower-margin operations, primarily the CCEAG structural change and the acquisitions of our interests in
Odwalla, the CCDA water brands and CBC. These decreases were partially offset by the sale and resulting deconsolidation of our Russian and Baltics bottling operations. Generally, bottling, canning and
vending operations produce higher net revenues but lower gross profit margins compared to concentrate and syrup operations. </FONT></P>

<UL>
