<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Selling, general and administrative expenses were approximately 7 percent higher in 2003 versus 2002. Approximately 4&nbsp;percentage points of
this increase were due to an overall weaker U.S. dollar (primarily compared to the euro). These expenses also increased by $75&nbsp;million as a result of increases for benefit plans, including
defined benefit pension plans, defined contribution pension plans, and postretirement health care and life insurance benefits plans. Selling expenses increased by approximately $32&nbsp;million due
to the inclusion of one additional month of operations for CCEAG in 2003 compared to 2002. The Seagram's mixers, the CCDA water brands and Evian transactions during 2002 resulted in an increase of
approximately $43&nbsp;million in selling, general and administrative expenses as a result of including full-year expenses in
2003 compared to only a portion of 2002. These increases were partially offset by effective management of operating expenses. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Acquisitions
of our interests in Odwalla, CCDA and CBC and the structural change of CCEAG increased selling expenses by $430&nbsp;million and general and administrative expenses by
$136&nbsp;million in 2002. These increases were partially offset by the sale and resulting deconsolidation of our Russian and Baltics bottling&nbsp;operations. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;142 and its related impact is discussed in Notes 1 and 4. Upon adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;142, intangible assets that have indefinite lives and goodwill
previously amortized are no longer amortized. Due to the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;142, amortization expense for 2002 was reduced by approximately $60&nbsp;million. Substantially all such
amortization expense was included in the general and administrative expenses line item. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
discussed in Notes 1 and 13, effective January&nbsp;1, 2002, our Company adopted the preferable fair value recognition provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;123, "Accounting for Stock-Based
Compensation" and selected the modified prospective transition method under the provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;148, "Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation&#151;Transition and Disclosure."
Prior to 2002, our Company accounted for stock-based compensation under the recognition and measurement provisions of APB Opinion No.&nbsp;25, "Accounting for Stock Issued to Employees" ("APB
No.&nbsp;25") and related interpretations. For stock options, no stock-based employee compensation expense was reflected in net income for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. In 2001, the
Company recorded $41&nbsp;million in stock-based compensation expense for its restricted stock plans. In 2003 and 2002, stock-based compensation expense was recognized as if the fair value method of
SFAS No.&nbsp;123 had been </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>36</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=38,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=111878,FOLIO='36',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]DM1030A.;35',USER='NLUCCA',CD='26-FEB-2004;15:06' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1030_1_37"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>applied
from its original effective date. Of the $422&nbsp;million recorded in 2003, $407&nbsp;million was recorded in selling, general and administrative expenses and $15&nbsp;million was
recorded in other operating charges. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A
stronger U.S. dollar relative to most major currencies partially offset the increases in selling, general and administrative expenses in 2002 compared to 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Pension Benefits.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net periodic cost for our defined benefit pension plans was $120&nbsp;million,
$72&nbsp;million and $62&nbsp;million, respectively, for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2003, 2002 and 2001. These expenses are included in general and administrative expenses. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
decrease in our expected weighted-average, long-term rate of return assumption, the decrease in our discount rate assumption and increased amortization of actuarial
losses increased our net
periodic pension cost by $48&nbsp;million in 2003 compared to 2002. Net periodic pension cost in 2004 is expected to be in the range of $20&nbsp;million to $25&nbsp;million higher than 2003 due
to a decrease in our discount rate assumptions and increased amortization of actuarial losses. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Refer
to Note&nbsp;14. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> <U>Other Operating Charges</U>  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating income in 2003 reflected the impact of $561&nbsp;million of expenses related to the 2003 streamlining initiatives. A majority of the charges related
to initiatives in North America and Germany. In North America, the Company integrated the operations of three separate North American business units&#151;Coca-Cola North America,
Minute Maid and Fountain. In Germany, CCEAG took steps to improve its efficiency in sales, distribution and manufacturing, and our German Division office also implemented streamlining initiatives.
Selected other operations also took steps to streamline their operations to improve overall efficiency and&nbsp;effectiveness. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
total streamlining initiative costs incurred for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 by operating segment were as follows (in millions): </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;These initiatives resulted in the separation of a total of approximately 3,700 associates in 2003, primarily in North America, Germany and Asia.
As a result of these streamlining initiatives, apart from the charge to 2003 earnings of $561&nbsp;million, we estimate that the Company's financial results benefited by approximately
$50&nbsp;million (pretax) in 2003 and will benefit by at least $100&nbsp;million (pretax) on an annualized basis beginning in&nbsp;2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Refer
to Note&nbsp;17. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>37</FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As demonstrated by the table above, the percentage contribution to operating income by each operating segment fluctuated from year to year.
Operating income was influenced by a variety of factors and events, primarily the following items: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>As
a result of streamlining charges, 2003 operating income was reduced by $561&nbsp;million as previously discussed. Refer to Note&nbsp;17.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>In
2003, as a result of the impact of adopting the fair value method of accounting for stock-based compensation under SFAS No.&nbsp;123, operating income was reduced by
$127&nbsp;million for North America, $26&nbsp;million for Africa, $55&nbsp;million for Asia, $54&nbsp;million for Europe, Eurasia and Middle East, $24&nbsp;million for Latin America and
$113&nbsp;million for Corporate. In 2002, as a result of the impact of adopting the fair value method of accounting for stock-based compensation under SFAS No.&nbsp;123, operating income was
reduced by $119&nbsp;million for North America, $24&nbsp;million for Africa, $51&nbsp;million for Asia, $51&nbsp;million for Europe, Eurasia and Middle East, $22&nbsp;million for Latin
America and $106&nbsp;million for Corporate. Refer to Notes&nbsp;13 and 19.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>In
2003, Europe, Eurasia and Middle East operating income significantly increased due to sound business fundamentals, innovation, strong marketing strategies, rigorous cost
management, positive currency trends and favorable weather during the summer months.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>In
2002, Latin America was negatively impacted by exchange fluctuations and challenging economic conditions, primarily in Argentina, Venezuela and Brazil.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>As
a result of the Company's receipt of a settlement related to a vitamin antitrust litigation matter, operating income in 2003 increased by $52&nbsp;million for
Corporate. Refer to Note&nbsp;16. </FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> <U>Interest Income and Interest Expense</U>  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2003, interest income decreased by $33&nbsp;million compared to 2002 primarily due to lower interest rates earned on short-term investments.
Nevertheless, the Company continues to benefit from cash invested in locations outside the United States earning higher interest rates than could be obtained within the United States. Conversely, a
majority of our interest expense is incurred on borrowings in the United States. Interest expense in 2003 decreased by $21&nbsp;million mainly as a result of both a decrease in average commercial
paper debt balances and lower interest rates for commercial paper borrowings. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A
majority of the 2002 decrease of $116&nbsp;million in interest income compared to 2001 was due to lower interest rates earned on short-term investments during 2002. The
2002 decrease in interest expense of $90&nbsp;million versus 2001 was due to both a decrease in average commercial paper borrowings and lower interest rates for commercial paper borrowings. The
decrease in interest expense for commercial paper borrowings was partially offset by increased interest expense on long-term debt related to the consolidation of CCEAG (refer to
Note&nbsp;18) and the issuance during 2002 of $750&nbsp;million of notes due June&nbsp;1, 2005. The proceeds from this $750&nbsp;million long-term debt issuance were used to reduce
current debt (refer to Note&nbsp;7). </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>38</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=40,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=400568,FOLIO='38',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]DN1030A.;13',USER='SSTANSE',CD='25-FEB-2004;21:07' -->
<A NAME="page_dn1030_1_39"> </A>
<BR>
<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> <U>Equity Income&#151;Net</U>  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Equity income for the majority of our investees increased during 2003 due to the overall improving health of the Coca-Cola bottling system around the
world. Our equity income for 2003 was negatively impacted by a $102&nbsp;million charge primarily related to a Latin American equity investee, as described below. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective
May&nbsp;6, 2003, one of our Company's Latin American equity method investees, Coca-Cola FEMSA, S.A. de C.V. ("Coca-Cola FEMSA"), consummated a merger
with another of the Company's Latin American equity method investees, Panamerican Beverages,&nbsp;Inc. ("Panamco"). Our Company received new Coca-Cola FEMSA shares in exchange for all
the Panamco shares previously held by the Company. Our Company's ownership interest in Coca-Cola FEMSA increased from 30&nbsp;percent to approximately 40&nbsp;percent as a result of
this
merger. This exchange of shares was treated as a nonmonetary exchange of similar productive assets, and no gain was recorded by our Company as a result of this merger. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
connection with the merger, Coca-Cola FEMSA management initiated steps to streamline and integrate the operations. This process included the closing of various
distribution centers and manufacturing plants. Furthermore, due to the challenging economic conditions and an uncertain political situation in Venezuela, certain intangible assets were determined to
be impaired and written down to their fair market value. During 2003, our Company recorded a noncash charge of $102&nbsp;million primarily related to these matters. This charge is included in the
line item equity income</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>&#151;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>net</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>.</B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
$232&nbsp;million increase in 2002 equity income</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>&#151;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>net, as compared to 2001, was due to the overall improving health of
the Coca-Cola bottling system around the world and the favorable impact of reduced amortization resulting from the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;142. Specific items with a positive impact to
equity income</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>&#151;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>net were the increase in equity income for CCE of approximately $209&nbsp;million due to improving trends in operating and
financial performance (which included a $90&nbsp;million favorable impact resulting from the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;142) and the reduction in amortization expenses of approximately
$60&nbsp;million for investments other than CCE resulting from the implementation of SFAS No.&nbsp;142. Due to the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;142, equity
income</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>&#151;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>net for 2002 increased by approximately $150&nbsp;million. These increases were offset by selected equity method investments in
Latin America that had been adversely impacted by economic difficulties, as well as our Company's share of impairment and restructuring charges taken by certain equity method investees in Latin
America during the third quarter of 2002. The Company's share of these charges was approximately $33&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
2002, our Company's share of income from equity method investees was also favorably impacted by a benefit related to our share of the gain on the sale by Cervejarias Kaiser S.A.
("Kaiser S.A.") of its interests in Cervejarias Kaiser Brazil,&nbsp;Ltda to Molson&nbsp;Inc. (refer to Note&nbsp;16). Approximately $21&nbsp;million of our share of the pretax gain from the
sale by Kaiser S.A. was recorded in the line item equity income&#151;net with the remaining portion, $22&nbsp;million, recorded in the line item other income (loss)&#151;net. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> <U>Other Income (Loss)&#151;Net</U>  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other income (loss)&#151;net was a net loss of $138&nbsp;million for 2003 compared to a net loss of $353&nbsp;million for 2002, a difference of
$215&nbsp;million. The significant portion of this difference related to a $157&nbsp;million charge (discussed below) in 2002, and no such charge applied to 2003. This line item in 2003 primarily
consisted of foreign exchange losses of $76&nbsp;million and accretion of $51&nbsp;million for the discounted value of the CCEAG&nbsp;liability. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other
income (loss)&#151;net in 2002 was principally composed of foreign currency exchange losses of approximately $118&nbsp;million, the accretion of the discounted value of
the CCEAG liability of approximately $38&nbsp;million (refer to Note&nbsp;18), the items discussed in this section below and minority interest accruals. The losses on currency exchange primarily
occurred in Latin America and Africa, which experienced significant devaluation of currencies. The increase in the minority interest accruals primarily related to the acquisitions of our interests in
CBC and CCDA. Refer to Note&nbsp;18. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>39</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=41,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=10662,FOLIO='39',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]DN1030A.;13',USER='SSTANSE',CD='25-FEB-2004;21:07' -->
<A NAME="page_dn1030_1_40"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the first quarter of 2002, our Company recorded a noncash pretax charge of approximately $157&nbsp;million, primarily related to the write-down of certain investments in
Latin America. This write-down reduced the carrying value of the investments to fair value. The charge was primarily the result of economic developments in Argentina during the first
quarter of 2002, including devaluation of the Argentine peso and the severity of the unfavorable economic conditions. The Company expects to realize a minimal tax benefit from this
write-down. The impact on 2002 diluted earnings per share was an after-tax reduction of approximately $0.06 per share. As previously noted, $22&nbsp;million of our share of
the pretax gain from the sale by Kaiser S.A. was recorded in the line item other income (loss)&#151;net in 2002. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> <U>Gains on Issuances of Stock by Equity Investees</U>  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;If and when an equity investee issues its stock to third parties at a price in excess of our book value, our Company's equity in the underlying net assets of that
investee increases. We generally record an increase to our investment account and a corresponding gain for these transactions. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2003, our Company recorded approximately $8&nbsp;million of noncash pretax gains on issuances of stock by equity investees. These gains primarily related to the issuance by CCE of
common stock valued at an amount greater than the book value per share of our investment in CCE. This transaction reduced our ownership interest in the total outstanding shares of CCE common stock by
less than 1&nbsp;percent. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
July&nbsp;2001, CCE completed its acquisition of Hondo Incorporated and Herbco Enterprises,&nbsp;Inc., collectively known as Herb Coca-Cola. The transaction was valued
at approximately $1.4&nbsp;billion, with approximately 30&nbsp;percent of the transaction funded with the issuance of approximately 25&nbsp;million shares of CCE common stock, and the remaining
portion funded through debt and assumed debt. The issuance of shares resulted in a noncash pretax gain for our Company of approximately $91&nbsp;million. This gain represents the increase in our
Company's equity in the underlying net assets of the related investee. This transaction reduced our ownership interest in the total outstanding shares of CCE common stock from approximately
40&nbsp;percent to approximately 38&nbsp;percent. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;No
gains on issuances of stock by equity investees were recorded to our statements of income during 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Refer
to Note&nbsp;3. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> <U>Income Taxes</U>  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our effective tax rate reflects tax benefits derived from significant operations outside the United States, which are generally taxed at rates lower than the U.S.
statutory rate of 35&nbsp;percent. During 2003, the Company's results benefited from a lower effective tax rate because of increased profit contributions from lower taxed locations resulting from
favorable currency exchange rates and other business conditions. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
effective tax rate of approximately 21&nbsp;percent for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 reflects the following: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>the
favorable resolution of various tax matters (approximately $50&nbsp;million) during the fourth quarter of 2003, partially offset by additional taxes primarily related
to the repatriation of funds;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>the
effective tax rate for the costs related to the streamlining initiatives of approximately 33&nbsp;percent;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>the
effective tax rate for the proceeds received related to the vitamin antitrust litigation matter of approximately 34&nbsp;percent;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>the
effective tax rate for the charge related to a Latin American equity investee of approximately 3&nbsp;percent; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>the
effective tax rate for all other pretax income of approximately 22&nbsp;percent. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>40</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=42,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=1006256,FOLIO='40',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]DN1030A.;13',USER='SSTANSE',CD='25-FEB-2004;21:07' -->
<A NAME="page_dn1030_1_41"> </A>
<UL>
<UL>
</UL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
effective tax rate for 2002 of 27.7&nbsp;percent included the impact of the following: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>the
effective tax rate for our share of the gain on the sale of Kaiser S.A. interests of approximately 39&nbsp;percent;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>we
concluded it was more likely than not that tax benefits would not be realized on the write-down of certain investments, primarily in Latin America; thus we
recorded a valuation allowance to offset the future tax benefit resulting in an increase of our effective tax rate; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>the
effective tax rate for all other pretax income of approximately 27&nbsp;percent. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
the first quarter of 2000, the U.S. and Japan taxing authorities entered into an Advance Pricing Agreement ("APA") whereby the level of royalties paid by Coca-Cola
(Japan) Company,&nbsp;Ltd. (our "Subsidiary") to our Company was established for the years 1993 through 2001. Pursuant to the terms of the APA, our Subsidiary filed amended returns for the
applicable periods reflecting the negotiated royalty rate. These amended returns resulted in the payment during the first and second quarters of 2000 of additional Japanese taxes. The effect on our
financial performance and our effective tax rate was not material, due primarily to offsetting tax credits utilized on our U.S. income tax returns. The majority of the offsetting tax credits were
realized in the first quarter of 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Looking
into 2004 and for the foreseeable future, based on current tax laws, the Company's effective tax rate on operations is expected to be approximately 25.5&nbsp;percent. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> <U>Cumulative Effect of Accounting Change for SFAS No.&nbsp;142, Net of Income Taxes</U>  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The cumulative effect of adopting SFAS No.&nbsp;142 as of January&nbsp;1, 2002 resulted in a noncash, after-tax decrease to net income of
$367&nbsp;million for Company operations and $559&nbsp;million for the Company's proportionate share of its equity method investees. The adoption of this accounting standard resulted in a pretax
reduction in 2002 amortization expense of approximately $60&nbsp;million, and an increase in 2002 equity income of approximately $150&nbsp;million. Refer to Notes 1 and 4. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> <U>Volume</U>  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We measure our sales volume in two ways: (1)&nbsp;gallons and (2)&nbsp;unit cases of finished products. "Gallons" is a unit of measurement for concentrates,
syrups, beverage bases, finished beverages and powders (in all cases, expressed in equivalent gallons of syrup) for all beverage products which are reportable as unit case volume. Most of our revenues
are based on gallon sales, as discussed under Item&nbsp;1 and MD&amp;A heading "Net Operating Revenues." Gallon sales and unit case volume are not necessarily equal during any given period. Items such
as seasonality, bottlers' inventory practices, supply point changes, timing of price increases and new product introductions can create differences between gallon sales and unit case volume. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Although
most of our Company's revenues are not based directly on unit case volume, we believe unit case volume is one of the measures of the underlying strength of the
Coca-Cola System because it measures trends at the consumer level. The Coca-Cola System sold approximately 19.4&nbsp;billion unit cases of our products in 2003 and
approximately 18.7&nbsp;billion unit cases in 2002. Approximate 2003 and 2002 unit case volume growth results are as follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=43,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=731249,FOLIO='41',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]DN1030A.;13',USER='SSTANSE',CD='25-FEB-2004;21:07' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_do1030_1_42"> </A> </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B><U>Liquidity, Capital Resources and Financial Position</U>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We believe our ability to generate cash from operations to reinvest in our business is one of our fundamental financial strengths. We expect cash flows from
operations to be strong in 2004 and in future years. For the five-year period from 2004 through 2008, we currently estimate that cumulative net cash provided from operating activities will
be in excess of $32&nbsp;billion. Accordingly, our Company expects to meet all our financial commitments and operating needs during this time frame. We expect to use cash generated from operating
activities primarily for dividends, share repurchases, acquisitions and aggregate contractual obligations. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> <U>Cash Flows from Operating Activities and Investing Activities</U>  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our statements of cash flows are summarized as follows (in millions): </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash flows from operating activities increased by 15&nbsp;percent for 2003 compared to 2002. The key component of this increase was increased
profits in 2003 versus 2002. The following items also significantly impacted cash flows: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Collection
by the Company in 2002 of approximately $280&nbsp;million, in connection with the APA reached between the United States and Japan in 2000, impacted the net
change in operating assets and liabilities for 2002. The APA established the level of royalties paid by Coca-Cola (Japan) Company Ltd. to our Company for the years 1993 through 2001.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Funding
of our primary qualified U.S. pension plan impacted our cash flows from operations. Approximately $166&nbsp;million was funded in 2003 compared to approximately
$124&nbsp;million in 2002.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Streamlining
costs in 2003 accounted for significant cash payments. Refer to Note&nbsp;17. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash
flows from operating activities increased by 15&nbsp;percent for 2002 compared to 2001, primarily as a result of improved worldwide business operating results. Additionally, as
stated above, collection of approximately $280&nbsp;million in connection with the APA increased our 2002 cash flows. These increases were partially offset by the following: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Funding
in 2002 of our primary qualified U.S. pension plan of approximately $124&nbsp;million as stated above. We made a payment of approximately $105&nbsp;million to
the primary qualified U.S. pension plan in&nbsp;2001.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>A
stronger U.S. dollar. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Purchases
of property, plant and equipment accounted for the most significant cash outlays for investing activities in each of three years ended December&nbsp;31, 2003. Our Company
currently estimates that purchases of property, plant and equipment in 2004 will be less than $1&nbsp;billion. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>42</FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Acquisitions and investments represented the next most significant investing activity accounting for $359&nbsp;million in 2003,
$544&nbsp;million in 2002 and $651&nbsp;million in 2001. Our single largest 2003 acquisition requiring the use of cash was the purchase of a 100&nbsp;percent ownership interest in Truesdale
Packaging Company LLC ("Truesdale") from CCE for cash consideration of approximately $58&nbsp;million. Truesdale owns a noncarbonated beverage production facility. In 2003, acquisitions of
intangible assets totaled approximately $142&nbsp;million. Of this amount, approximately $88&nbsp;million related to the Company's acquisition of certain intangible assets with indefinite lives,
primarily trademarks and brands in various parts of the world. None of these trademarks and brands was considered individually significant. Additionally, the Company acquired certain brands and
related contractual rights from Panamco valued at $54&nbsp;million in the Latin America operating segment with an estimated useful life of 10&nbsp;years. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2002, our Company expended cash of approximately $328&nbsp;million for acquisitions of our interests in CBC and CCDA. In 2001, our Company completed several acquisitions; however,
none was individually material. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Refer
to Note&nbsp;18. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
July&nbsp;2003, we made a convertible loan of approximately $133&nbsp;million to The Coca-Cola Bottling Company of Egypt ("TCCBCE"). The loan is convertible into
preferred shares of TCCBCE upon receipt of governmental approvals. Additionally, upon certain defaults under either the loan agreement or the terms of the preferred shares, we have the ability to
convert the loan or the preferred shares into common shares. At December&nbsp;31, 2003, our Company owned approximately 42&nbsp;percent of the common shares of TCCBCE. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
November&nbsp;2003, CCHBC approved a share capital reduction totaling approximately 473&nbsp;million euros and the return of 2 euros per share to all share owners. In
December&nbsp;2003, our Company received our share capital return payment from CCHBC equivalent to $136&nbsp;million. Refer to Note&nbsp;2. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Issuances and payments of debt included both short-term and long-term financing activities. On December&nbsp;31, 2003,
we had $1,576&nbsp;million in lines of credit and other short-term credit facilities available, </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>43</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=45,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=721069,FOLIO='43',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]DO1030A.;41',USER='SSTANSE',CD='25-FEB-2004;22:06' -->
<A NAME="page_do1030_1_44"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>of&nbsp;which
approximately $246&nbsp;million was outstanding. This entire $246&nbsp;million related to our international&nbsp;operations. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
issuances of debt in 2003 primarily included approximately $304&nbsp;million of issuances of commercial paper with maturities 90&nbsp;days or less and approximately
$715&nbsp;million of issuances of commercial paper with maturities more than 90&nbsp;days. The payments of debt in 2003 primarily included approximately $907&nbsp;million related to commercial
paper with maturities more than 90&nbsp;days and $150&nbsp;million of long-term debt. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
issuances of debt in 2002 primarily included approximately $832&nbsp;million of issuances of commercial paper with maturities of more than 90&nbsp;days and $750&nbsp;million in
issuances of long-term notes due June&nbsp;1, 2005. The payments of debt in 2002 primarily included approximately $816&nbsp;million related to commercial paper with maturities of more
than 90&nbsp;days, net payments of $1,280&nbsp;million related to commercial paper with maturities of 90&nbsp;days or less and the $150&nbsp;million redemption of 6<SUP>5</SUP>/<SMALL>8</SMALL> percent
U.S. dollar notes. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
issuances of debt in 2001 primarily included approximately $2,383&nbsp;million of issuances of commercial paper with maturities of more than 90&nbsp;days. In 2001, we also had a
$500&nbsp;million issuance of long-term debt. The payments of debt in 2001 primarily included approximately $3,864&nbsp;million related to commercial paper with maturities of more than
90&nbsp;days. Net issuances related to commercial paper with maturities of 90&nbsp;days or less were $40&nbsp;million in 2001. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2003, 2002 and 2001, the Company repurchased common stock under the share repurchase plan authorized by our Board of Directors in October&nbsp;1996. As strong cash flows are
expected to continue in the future, the Company currently expects to increase its 2004 share repurchase levels to at least $2&nbsp;billion. Refer to MD&amp;A heading "Financial Strategies and Risk
Management." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Dividends
have increased every year for each of the last 42 years, and we believe that for the foreseeable future, our Board of Directors intends to increase our dividends. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> <U>Off&#150;Balance Sheet Arrangements and Aggregate Contractual Obligations</U>  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Off&#150;Balance Sheet Arrangements.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In accordance with the definition under Securities and
Exchange Commission rules, the following qualify as off&#150;balance sheet arrangements: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>any
obligation under certain guarantees or contracts;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>a
retained or contingent interest in assets transferred to an unconsolidated entity or similar entity or similar arrangement that serves as credit, liquidity or market risk
support to that entity for such assets;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>any
obligation under certain derivative instruments;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>any
obligation under a material variable interest held by the registrant in an unconsolidated entity that provides financing, liquidity, market risk or credit risk support
to the registrant, or engages in leasing, hedging or research and development services with the registrant. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following discussion addresses each of the above items for our Company. On December&nbsp;31, 2003, our Company was contingently liable for guarantees of indebtedness owed by third
parties in the amount of $280&nbsp;million. Management concluded that the likelihood of any material amounts being paid by our Company is not probable. In December&nbsp;2003, we granted a
$250&nbsp;million stand-by line of credit to Coca-Cola FEMSA with normal market terms. We do not provide any other guarantees. As of December&nbsp;31, 2003, we were not
directly liable for the debt of any unconsolidated entity, and we do not have any retained or contingent interest in assets as defined above. Additionally, our Company recognizes all derivative
instruments as either assets or liabilities at fair value in our balance sheets. Refer to Notes 10 and 11. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
Company has equity ownership interests in bottlers that we currently account for under the equity method of accounting. For certain entities, primarily bottlers, our Company holds
variable interests such as providing financing and guarantees, in addition to our equity investments. As a result, these entities are </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>44</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=46,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=29600,FOLIO='44',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]DO1030A.;41',USER='SSTANSE',CD='25-FEB-2004;22:06' -->
<A NAME="page_do1030_1_45"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>considered
variable interest entities, and we expect to consolidate such variable interest entities effective March&nbsp;31, 2004. Refer to Note&nbsp;1. The difference between consolidation and
the equity method impacts certain financial ratios because of the presentation of the detailed line items reported in the financial statements. However, consolidated net income for the period and our
share-owners' equity at the end of the period are the same whether the investment is accounted for under the equity method or is consolidated. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aggregate Contractual Obligations.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 2003, the Company's contractual
obligations, including payments due by period, are as follows (in millions): </FONT></P>

<TD WIDTH="98%"><FONT SIZE=2>Refer to Note&nbsp;6 for information regarding short-term loans and notes payable. Upon payment of commercial paper borrowings, we typically expect to issue new commercial paper borrowings. Lines of credit and other
short-term borrowings are expected to fluctuate depending upon current liquidity needs, especially at international subsidiaries.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
<SUP>2</SUP></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="98%"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
Refer to Note&nbsp;7 for information regarding long-term debt. We expect to settle such long-term debt by several options including cash flows from operations, issuance of commercial paper or issuance of other long-term debt.</FONT></TD>

<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
<SUP>3</SUP></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="98%"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
We calculated estimated interest payments for short-term loans and notes payable and long-term debt as follows. For fixed-rate debt and term debt, we calculated interest based on the applicable rates and payment dates. For variable-rate debt and/or
nonterm debt, we estimated interest rates and payment dates based on our determination of the most likely scenarios for each relevant debt instrument. We typically expect to settle such interest payments with cash flows from operations and short-term
borrowings.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
<SUP>4</SUP></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="98%"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
Refer to Note&nbsp;11 for information regarding marketing and other commitments. We expect to fund these commitments with cash flows from operations. We have excluded expected payments for volume-related programs, such as payments to unconsolidated
bottlers or customers that are generally determined and committed to on an annual basis.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
<SUP>5</SUP></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="98%"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
The purchase commitments include agreements to purchase goods or services that are enforceable and legally binding and that specify all significant terms, including open purchase orders. We expect to fund these commitments with cash flows from
operations.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
<SUP>6</SUP></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="98%"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
The amount represents the estimated cash to be paid to CCEAG share owners. Refer to Note&nbsp;18 for discussion of the present value of our liability to CCEAG share owners. We will consider several options to settle this liability including cash
flows from operations, issuance of commercial paper, or issuance of other long-term debt.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>
<SUP>7</SUP></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="98%"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=47,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=201980,FOLIO='45',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]DO1030A.;41',USER='SSTANSE',CD='25-FEB-2004;22:06' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_dq1030_1_46"> </A> </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;87, "Employers' Accounting for Pensions," and SFAS No.&nbsp;106, "Employers' Accounting for Postretirement Benefits Other Than Pensions," the total
accrued benefit liability for pension and other postretirement benefit plans recognized as of December&nbsp;31, 2003 is $1,084&nbsp;million. Refer to Note&nbsp;14. This accrued liability is
included in the balance sheet line item other liabilities. This amount is impacted by, among other items, funding levels, changes in plan demographics and assumptions and investment return on plan
assets. Because the accrued liability does not represent expected liquidity needs, we did not include this amount in the contractual obligations table. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
fund our U.S. qualified pension plans in accordance with ERISA regulations for the minimum annual required contribution and in accordance with IRS regulations for the maximum annual
allowable tax deduction. The minimum required contribution for our primary qualified U.S. pension plan for the 2004 plan year is $0 and is anticipated to remain $0 for at least the next several years
due to large contributions made to the plan over the past three years. Therefore, we did not include any amounts as a contractual obligation in the above table. However, the following provides
information about 2004 contributions. We contributed $100&nbsp;million to the primary U.S. qualified pension plan in January&nbsp;2004, and we anticipate contributing up to an additional
$65&nbsp;million to this plan later in 2004, or contributing up to the maximum deductible amount. Furthermore, we expect to contribute up to $55&nbsp;million to the U.S. postretirement health care
benefit plan during 2004. We funded the $100&nbsp;million payment with cash flows from operations, and we generally expect to fund all future contributions with cash flows from operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
international pension plans are funded in accordance with local laws and income tax regulations. We do not expect contributions to these plans to be material in 2004 or years
thereafter. Therefore, no amounts have been included in the table above. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of December&nbsp;31, 2003, the projected benefit obligation of the U.S. qualified pension plans was $1,356&nbsp;million, and the fair value of plan assets was
$1,467&nbsp;million. As of December&nbsp;31, 2003, the projected benefit obligation of all pension plans other than the U.S. qualified pension plans was $1,139&nbsp;million, and the fair value
of all other pension plan assets was $557&nbsp;million. The majority of this difference is attributable to an international pension plan for certain non-U.S. employees that is unfunded
due to tax law restrictions, as well as our unfunded U.S. nonqualified pension plans. These U.S. nonqualified pension plans provide benefits for certain members of management that are not permitted to
be funded through a qualified plan because of limits imposed by the Internal Revenue Code. Disclosure of amounts in the above table regarding expected benefit payments to unfunded pension plans and
our other postretirement benefit plans cannot be properly reflected due to the ongoing nature of the obligations of these plans. However, in
order to inform the reader about such payments, we anticipate annual payments to be in the range of approximately $45&nbsp;million to $55&nbsp;million in 2004 and remain at or near this annual
level for the next several years. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Deferred
income tax liabilities as of December&nbsp;31, 2003 were $337&nbsp;million. Refer to Note&nbsp;15. This amount is not included in the total contractual obligations table
because we believe this presentation would not be meaningful. Deferred income tax liabilities are calculated based on temporary differences between the tax basis of assets and liabilities and their
book basis that will result in taxable amounts in future years when the book basis is settled. The results of these calculations do not have any connection with the amount of cash taxes to be paid in
any future periods. As a result, scheduling deferred income tax liabilities as payments due by period could be misleading because this scheduling would not relate to liquidity needs. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Minority
interests of $191&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2003 for consolidated entities in which we do not have a 100&nbsp;percent ownership interest were recorded in the
balance sheet line item other liabilities. Such minority interests are not liabilities requiring the use of cash or other resources; therefore, this amount is excluded from the contractual obligations
table. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>46</FONT></P>

<A NAME="page_dq1030_1_47"> </A>
<BR>
<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> <U>Exchange</U>  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our international operations are subject to certain opportunities and risks, including currency fluctuations and governmental actions. We closely monitor our
operations in each country and seek to adopt appropriate strategies that are responsive to changing economic and political environments and to fluctuations in foreign&nbsp;currencies. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
use 52 functional currencies. Due to our global operations, weaknesses in some of these currencies are often offset by strengths in others. In 2003, 2002 and 2001, the
weighted-average exchange rates for foreign currencies in which the Company conducts operations (all operating currencies), and for certain individual currencies, strengthened (weakened) against the
U.S. dollar as follows: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;These percentages do not include the effects of our hedging activities and, therefore, do not reflect the actual impact of fluctuations in
exchange on our operating results. Our foreign currency management program is designed to mitigate, over time, a portion of the impact of exchange on net income and earnings per share. Taking into
account the effects of our hedging activities, the impact of a weaker U.S. dollar
increased our operating income by approximately 2&nbsp;percent in 2003. The impact of a stronger U.S. dollar reduced our operating income by approximately 3&nbsp;percent in 2002 and approximately
5&nbsp;percent in 2001. Based on forecasts as of December&nbsp;31, 2003, the Company expects exchange to have a positive impact on our 2004 operating results when compared to 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Exchange
gains (losses)&#151;net amounted to $(76) million in 2003, $(118)&nbsp;million in 2002 and $(9) million in 2001 and were recorded in other income (loss)&#151;net
in our statements of income. Exchange gains (losses)&#151;net include the remeasurement of monetary assets and liabilities from certain currencies into functional currencies and the costs of
hedging certain exposures of our balance sheet. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Refer
to Note&nbsp;10. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> <U>Financial Position</U>  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our balance sheet as of December&nbsp;31, 2003, as compared to our balance sheet as of December&nbsp;31, 2002, was impacted by the following: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>A
$1,102&nbsp;million increase in cash and cash equivalents due primarily to increased cash flows from operations;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
increase in our equity method investment in Coca-Cola FEMSA of $327&nbsp;million and the decrease in equity method investments, other, principally bottling
companies, of $357&nbsp;million were primarily due to the merger of Coca-Cola FEMSA and Panamco. Refer to Note&nbsp;2. The overall increase in equity method investments of
approximately $487&nbsp;million from December&nbsp;31, 2002 to December&nbsp;31, 2003 was primarily due to a benefit in 2003 currency translation and an increase in 2003 equity income, net of
dividends.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
increase in other assets from $2,694&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2002 to $3,322&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2003 resulted primarily from Company
contributions of $166&nbsp;million to the primary U.S. qualified pension plan and a reversal of $191&nbsp;million related to the additional minimum liability for the Company's </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

U.S. qualified pension plan because the plan did not have an unfunded accumulated benefit obligation as of December&nbsp;31, 2003. </FONT></P>

</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
overall increase in total assets as of December&nbsp;31, 2003 compared to December&nbsp;31, 2002 primarily related to the increase in cash and cash equivalents
mentioned above (which impacted our Corporate operating segment) and the impact of a stronger euro (which impacted our Europe, Eurasia and Middle East operating segment) and Japanese yen (which
impacted our Asia operating segment), partially offset by the impact of weakening currencies impacting the Latin America segment. </FONT></DD></DL>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> <U>Impact of Inflation and Changing Prices</U>  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Inflation affects the way we operate in many markets around the world. In general, we believe that over time we are able to increase prices to counteract the
majority of the inflationary effects of increasing costs and to generate sufficient cash flows to maintain our productive capability. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><U>Forward-Looking Statements</U>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Certain written and oral statements made by our Company and subsidiaries or with the approval of an authorized executive officer of our Company may constitute
"forward-looking statements" as defined under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, including statements made in this report and other filings with the Securities and Exchange
Commission. Generally, the words "believe," "expect," "intend," "estimate," "anticipate," "project," "will" and similar expressions identify forward-looking statements, which generally are not
historical in nature. All statements that address operating performance, events or developments that we expect or anticipate will occur in the future&#151;including statements relating to
volume growth, share of sales and earnings per share growth and statements expressing general optimism about future operating results&#151;are forward-looking statements. Forward-looking
statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from our Company's historical experience and our present expectations or projections. As
and when made, management believes that these forward-looking statements are reasonable. However, caution should be taken not to place undue reliance on any such forward-looking statements since such
statements speak only
as of the date when made. The Company undertakes no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following are some of the factors that could cause our Company's actual results to differ materially from the expected results described in or underlying our Company's
forward-looking statements: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Economic
and political conditions, especially in international markets, including civil unrest, product boycotts, governmental changes and restrictions on the ability to
transfer capital across borders. Without limiting the preceding sentence, the current unstable economic and political conditions and civil unrest in the Middle East, North Korea or elsewhere, the
unstable situation in Iraq, or the continuation or escalation of terrorism, could have adverse impacts on our Company's business results or financial condition.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Changes
in the nonalcoholic beverages business environment. These include, without limitation, changes in consumer preferences, including changes based on health and
nutrition considerations; competitive product and pricing pressures; and our ability to gain or maintain share of sales in the global market as a result of actions by competitors. Factors such as
these could impact our earnings, share of sales and volume growth.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Foreign
currency rate fluctuations, interest rate fluctuations and other capital market conditions. Most of our exposures to capital markets, including foreign currency and
interest rates, are managed on a consolidated basis, which allows us to net certain exposures and, thus, take advantage of any natural offsets. We use derivative financial instruments to reduce our
net exposure to financial risks. There can </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>48</FONT></P>

<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Adverse
weather conditions, which could reduce demand for Company products.

effectiveness of our advertising, marketing and promotional programs.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Fluctuations
in the cost and availability of raw materials, the cost of energy, transportation and other necessary services; our ability to maintain favorable supplier
arrangements and relationships; and our ability to avoid disruptions in production output caused by events such as natural disasters, power outages, labor strikes or the like.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Our
ability to achieve earnings forecasts, which are generated based on projected volumes and sales of many product types, some of which are more profitable than others.
There can be no assurance that we will achieve the projected level or mix of product sales.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Our
ability to effectively align ourselves with our bottling system as we focus on increasing the investment in our brands; seeking efficiencies throughout the supply chain;
delivering more value for our customers; and better meeting the needs of our consumers.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Changes
in laws and regulations, including changes in accounting standards, taxation requirements (including tax rate changes, new tax laws and revised tax law
interpretations), laws concerning food and beverages, competition laws, employment laws and environmental laws in domestic or foreign&nbsp;jurisdictions.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Our
ability to penetrate developing and emerging markets, which also depends on economic and political conditions, and how well we are able to acquire or form strategic
business alliances with local bottlers and make necessary infrastructure enhancements to production facilities, distribution networks, sales equipment and technology. Moreover, the supply of products
in developing markets must match the customers' demand for those products, and due to product price and cultural differences, there can be no assurance of product acceptance in any particular market.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
uncertainties of litigation, as well as other risks and uncertainties detailed from time to time in our Company's Securities and Exchange Commission filings. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

foregoing list of important factors is not exclusive. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Refer to Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>55</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=57,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=564509,FOLIO='55',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]FG1030A.;36',USER='SSTANSE',CD='25-FEB-2004;22:40' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_fi1030_1_56"> </A> </FONT>
<BR><FONT SIZE=2><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS  </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>The Coca-Cola Company and Subsidiaries  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>NOTE 1: ORGANIZATION AND SUMMARY OF SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Organization  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Coca-Cola Company is predominantly a manufacturer, distributor and marketer of nonalcoholic beverage concentrates and syrups. In these notes, the
terms "Company," "we," "us" or "our" mean The Coca-Cola Company and all subsidiaries included in the consolidated financial statements. Operating in more than 200 countries worldwide, we
primarily sell our concentrates and syrups, as well as some finished beverages, to bottling and canning operations, distributors, fountain wholesalers and fountain retailers. We also market and
distribute juices and juice drinks, sports drinks, water products, teas, coffees and other beverage products. Additionally, we have ownership interests in numerous bottling and canning operations.
Significant markets for our products exist in all the world's geographic regions. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Basis of Presentation and Consolidation  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our consolidated financial statements are prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States. Our Company consolidates all
entities that we control by ownership of a
majority voting interest. Refer to heading "New Accounting Standards" for a discussion of variable interest entities. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
use the equity method to account for our investments for which we have the ability to exercise significant influence over operating and financial policies. Consolidated net income
includes our Company's share of the net earnings of these companies. The difference between consolidation and the equity method impacts certain financial ratios because of the presentation of the
detailed line items reported in the financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
use the cost method to account for our investments in companies that we do not control and for which we do not have the ability to exercise significant influence over operating and
financial policies. In accordance with the cost method, these investments are recorded at cost or fair value, as appropriate. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
eliminate from our financial results all significant intercompany transactions, including the intercompany portion of transactions with equity method investees. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Certain
amounts in the prior years' financial statements have been reclassified to conform to the current-year presentation. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Use of Estimates and Assumptions  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The preparation of our financial statements requires us to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues and
expenses and the disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities in our financial statements and accompanying notes. Although these estimates are based on our knowledge of current events and actions
we may undertake in the future, actual results may ultimately differ from estimates and assumptions. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Risks and Uncertainties  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company's operations, at times, could be adversely affected by restrictions on imports and exports and sources of supply; a prolonged labor strike; duties or
tariffs; changes in governmental regulations; the introduction of additional measures to control inflation; changes in the rate or method of taxation; the imposition of additional restrictions on
currency conversion and remittances abroad; the expropriation of private </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>56</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=58,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=228935,FOLIO='56',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]FI1030A.;20',USER='ARUSS',CD='26-FEB-2004;16:55' -->
<A NAME="page_fi1030_1_57"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>enterprise;
or product issues such as a product recall. In addition, policy concerns particular to the United States with respect to a country in which the Company has operations could adversely
affect our operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
Company monitors our operations with a view to minimizing the impact to our overall business that could arise as a result of the risks inherent in our business. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Revenue Recognition  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our Company recognizes revenue when title of our products is transferred to our bottling partners or our&nbsp;customers. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Advertising Costs  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our Company expenses production costs of print, radio, television and other advertisements as of the first date the advertisements take place. Advertising
expenses included in selling, general and administrative expenses were approximately $1.9&nbsp;billion in 2003, approximately $1.8&nbsp;billion in 2002 and approximately $2.0&nbsp;billion in
2001. As of December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002, advertising production costs of approximately $190&nbsp;million and $170&nbsp;million, respectively, were recorded in prepaid expenses and other
assets and in noncurrent other assets in our balance sheets. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Stock-Based Compensation  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our Company currently sponsors stock option plans and restricted stock award plans. Refer to Note&nbsp;13. Prior to 2002, our Company accounted for those plans
under the recognition and measurement provisions of APB Opinion No.&nbsp;25, "Accounting for Stock Issued to Employees" ("APB No.&nbsp;25") and related interpretations. No stock-based employee
compensation expense for stock options was reflected in net income for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001, as all stock options granted under those plans had an exercise price equal to the fair
market value of the underlying common stock on the date of grant. Effective January&nbsp;1, 2002, our Company adopted the preferable fair value recognition provisions of Statement of Financial
Accounting Standards ("SFAS") No.&nbsp;123, "Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation." Our Company selected the modified prospective method of adoption described in SFAS No.&nbsp;148, "Accounting
for Stock-Based Compensation&#151;Transition and Disclosure." Compensation cost recognized in 2003 and 2002 is the same as that which would have been recognized had the fair value method of
SFAS No.&nbsp;123 been applied from its original effective date. In accordance with the modified prospective method of adoption, results for years prior to 2002 have not been restated. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>57</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
