<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2003, the Company established a program to provide Performance Share Unit Awards under the 1989 Restricted Stock Award Plan to executives.
Awards for the 2004&#150;2006 performance period were made in December&nbsp;2003 at a fair value of $46.78 per share. The performance measure for these awards is compound annual growth in
earnings per share, as adjusted for certain items approved by the Board of Directors ("adjusted EPS"). The number of performance share units earned shall be determined at the end of the
three-year performance period and will result in an award at that time of restricted stock under the 1989 Restricted Stock Award Plan. Restrictions on such stock lapse on the fifth
anniversary of the original award date. The target award made in December&nbsp;2003 was 798,931 shares and requires 11&nbsp;percent adjusted EPS growth over the performance period. The maximum
award is 1,198,397 shares, if adjusted EPS growth is 13&nbsp;percent or more, and </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>84</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=86,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=827508,FOLIO='84',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]FM1030B.;36',USER='MTITUSS',CD='26-FEB-2004;15:14' -->
<A NAME="page_fm1030_1_85"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>the
minimum award is 399,466 shares if adjusted EPS is at 8&nbsp;percent. Below 8&nbsp;percent adjusted EPS growth, there is no award of restricted shares at the end of the period. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2003, 200,000 shares of five-year performance-based restricted stock were cancelled at an average fair value of $46.88 per share. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2002, 50,000 shares of four-year performance-based restricted stock were granted at an average fair value of $46.88 per share. The release of the shares is subject to the
Company's achievement of a minimum of 11&nbsp;percent annual growth in earnings per share over the four-year measurement period, as adjusted for certain items approved by the Board of
Directors. In 2002, the Company also promised to grant 50,000 shares at the end of three years and 75,000 shares at the end of four years if the Company achieved predefined performance targets over
the respective measurement periods. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2000, 270,000 shares of three-year performance-based and 2,025,000 shares of five-year performance-based restricted stock were granted. The release of these
shares was contingent upon the Company achieving certain predefined performance targets over the three-year and five-year measurement periods, respectively. Participants were
entitled to vote and receive dividends on these shares during the measurement period. The Company also promised to grant 180,000 shares of stock at the end of three years and 200,000 shares at the end
of five years to certain employees if the Company achieved predefined performance targets over the respective measurement periods. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
May&nbsp;2001, all performance-based restricted stock awards and promises made to grant shares in the future were cancelled, with the exception of 150,000 shares of
five-year performance-based restricted stock. New awards for the same number of cancelled shares, with the exception of the promises made in 2000 to grant 200,000 shares at the end of five
years, were granted at an average fair value of $47.88 per share. The release of the shares is subject to the Company's achievement of a minimum of 11&nbsp;percent annual growth in earnings per
share over the respective measurement periods, as adjusted for certain items approved by the Board of Directors. In 2001, an additional 10,000 shares of three-year performance-based
restricted stock and 50,000 shares of five-year performance-based
restricted stock were granted at an average fair value of $46.22 per share and $45.70 per share, respectively, with predefined performance targets to be achieved over the respective measurement
periods. In 2001, an additional 250,000 shares of five-year performance-based restricted stock were granted at an average fair value of $46.80 per share. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
all cases where the measurement period ended in 2003, the performance conditions for the three-year performance-based restricted stock grants and the promises to grant
stock at the end of the three-year period were not&nbsp;achieved. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>NOTE 14: PENSION AND OTHER POSTRETIREMENT BENEFIT PLANS  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our Company sponsors and/or contributes to pension and postretirement health care and life insurance benefit plans covering substantially all U.S. employees. We
also sponsor nonqualified, unfunded defined benefit pension plans for certain members of management. In addition, our Company and its subsidiaries have various pension plans and other forms of
postretirement arrangements outside the United States. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Total
expense for all benefit plans, including defined benefit pension plans, defined contribution pension plans, and postretirement health care and life insurance benefits plans,
amounted to $243&nbsp;million in 2003, $168&nbsp;million in 2002 and $142&nbsp;million in 2001. In addition, in 2003 the Company recorded a charge of $23&nbsp;million for special retirement
benefits and curtailment costs as part of the streamlining costs discussed in Note&nbsp;17. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>85</FONT></P>

<A NAME="page_fm1030_1_86"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
Company uses a measurement date of December&nbsp;31 for substantially all of our pension and postretirement benefit plans. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The accumulated benefit obligation for our pension plans was $2,145&nbsp;million and $1,893&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002,
respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
total projected benefit obligation and fair value of plan assets for the pension plans with projected benefit obligations in excess of plan assets were $941&nbsp;million and
$311&nbsp;million, respectively, as of December&nbsp;31, 2003 and $2,016&nbsp;million and $1,262&nbsp;million, respectively, as of December&nbsp;31, 2002. The total accumulated benefit
obligation and fair value of plan assets for the pension plans with accumulated benefit obligations in excess of plan assets were $770&nbsp;million and $274&nbsp;million, respectively, as of
December&nbsp;31, 2003 and $1,733&nbsp;million and $1,243&nbsp;million, respectively, as of December&nbsp;31, 2002. </FONT></P>

<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=89,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=428243,FOLIO='87',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]FN1030A.;24',USER='JGUERRE',CD='26-FEB-2004;18:29' -->
<A NAME="page_fn1030_1_88"> </A>
<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Assumptions  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The weighted-average assumptions used in computing the benefit obligations are as follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"><TABLE WIDTH="83%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH WIDTH="57%" ALIGN="LEFT"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=3 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1>Pension Benefits</FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
<TH WIDTH="6%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=3 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1>Other Benefits</FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH WIDTH="57%" ALIGN="LEFT"><FONT SIZE=1>December&nbsp;31,</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH WIDTH="5%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=1><B>2003</B></FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="6%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>

streamlining initiatives. Refer to Note&nbsp;17. The discount rate assumption used to determine 2003 net periodic benefit cost for these U.S. plans was 6<SUP>3</SUP>/<SMALL>4</SMALL> percent prior to the remeasurement and
6<SUP>1</SUP>/<SMALL>2</SMALL> percent subsequent to the remeasurement. This change in the discount rate is reflected in the 2003 weighted-average discount rate of 6&nbsp;percent for all pension benefit plans and
6<SUP>1</SUP>/<SMALL>2</SMALL>&nbsp;percent for other benefit plans.</FONT></TD>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investment objectives for the Company's U.S. plan assets are to: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(1)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>optimize
the long-term return on plan assets at an acceptable level of risk;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(2)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>maintain
a broad diversification across asset classes and among investment managers;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(3)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>maintain
careful control of the risk level within each asset class; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(4)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>focus
on a long-term return objective. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Asset
allocation targets promote optimal expected return and volatility characteristics given the long-term time horizon for fulfilling the obligations of the pension plans.
Selection of the targeted asset allocation for U.S. plan assets was based upon a review of the expected return and risk characteristics of each asset class, as well as the correlation of returns among
asset classes. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investment
guidelines are established with each investment manager. These guidelines provide the parameters within which the investment managers agree to operate, including criteria that
determine eligible and ineligible securities, diversification requirements and credit quality standards, where applicable. Unless exceptions have been approved, investment managers are prohibited from
buying or selling commodities, futures or option contracts, as well as from short selling of securities. Furthermore, investment managers agree to obtain written approval for deviations from stated
investment style or guidelines. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of December&nbsp;31, 2003, no investment manager was responsible for more than 10&nbsp;percent of total U.S. plan assets. In addition, diversification requirements for each
investment manager prevent a single security or other investment from exceeding 10&nbsp;percent, at historical cost, of the total U.S. plan assets. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;External
consultants were engaged to conduct an asset and liability study in order to determine the most appropriate investment strategy and asset mix for our U.S. plan assets. To
develop our expected long-term rate of return assumption on U.S. plan assets, our Company uses long-term historical return information for the </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>89</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=91,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=861443,FOLIO='89',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]FN1030A.;24',USER='JGUERRE',CD='26-FEB-2004;18:29' -->
<A NAME="page_fn1030_1_90"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>targeted
asset mix identified in the asset and liability study. Adjustments are made to the expected long-term rate of return assumption when deemed necessary based upon revised
expectations of future investment performance of the overall capital markets. The expected long-term rate of return assumption used in computing 2003 net periodic pension cost for the U.S.
plans was 8.5 percent. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Contributions  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We contributed $100&nbsp;million to the primary qualified U.S. pension plan in January&nbsp;2004, and we anticipate contributing up to an additional
$65&nbsp;million to this plan later in 2004. We expect to contribute up to $55&nbsp;million to the U.S. postretirement benefit plan during 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our effective tax rate reflects the tax benefits from having significant operations outside the United States that are taxed at rates lower than
the statutory rate of 35&nbsp;percent. In 2003, our effective tax rate reflects further benefit from realization of tax benefits on charges related to streamlining initiatives recorded in locations
with tax rates higher than our effective tax rate. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2003, management concluded that it was more likely than not that tax benefits would not be realized on Coca-Cola FEMSA's write-down of intangible assets in
Latin American in connection with its merger with Panamco. Refer to Note&nbsp;2. In 2002, management concluded that it was more likely than not that tax benefits would not be realized with respect
to principally all of the items disclosed in
Note&nbsp;16. Accordingly, valuation allowances were recorded to offset the future tax benefit of these items resulting in an increase in our effective tax rate. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Undistributed
earnings of the Company's foreign subsidiaries amounted to approximately $8.2&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2003. Those earnings are considered to be indefinitely
reinvested and, accordingly, no U.S. federal and state income taxes have been provided thereon. Upon distribution of those earnings in the form of dividends or otherwise, the Company would be subject
to both U.S. income taxes (subject to an adjustment for foreign tax credits) and withholding taxes payable to the various foreign countries. Determination of the amount of unrecognized deferred U.S.
income tax liability is not practicable because of the complexities associated with its hypothetical calculation; however, unrecognized foreign tax credits would be available to reduce a portion of
the U.S. liability. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>91</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=93,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=778463,FOLIO='91',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]FO1030A.;53',USER='NDEWIND',CD='26-FEB-2004;15:27' -->
<A NAME="page_fo1030_1_92"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
tax effects of temporary differences and carryforwards that give rise to deferred tax assets and liabilities consist of the following (in millions): </FONT></P>

<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"><TABLE WIDTH="80%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>

<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=1><B>2003</B></FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=1>2002</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH COLSPAN=8 ALIGN="CENTER"><HR NOSHADE></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"><TABLE WIDTH="80%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2><SUP>1</SUP></FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="98%"><FONT SIZE=2>Deferred tax assets of $446&nbsp;million and $358&nbsp;million were included in the line item other assets at December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002, respectively.</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE></DIV>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002, we had approximately $160&nbsp;million and $129&nbsp;million, respectively, of net deferred tax assets
located in countries outside the United States. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
December&nbsp;31, 2003, we had $2,511&nbsp;million of loss carryforwards available to reduce future taxable income. Loss carryforwards of $791&nbsp;million must be utilized
within the next five years; $673&nbsp;million must be utilized within the next 10&nbsp;years; and the remainder can be utilized over an indefinite period. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>NOTE&nbsp;16: SIGNIFICANT OPERATING AND NONOPERATING ITEMS  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the first quarter of 2003, the Company reached a settlement with certain defendants in a vitamin antitrust litigation matter. In that litigation, the Company
alleged that certain vitamin manufacturers participated in a global conspiracy to fix the price of some vitamins, including vitamins used in the manufacture of some of the Company's products. During
the first quarter of 2003, the Company received a settlement relating to this litigation of approximately $52&nbsp;million on a pretax basis, or $0.01 per share on an after-tax basis.
The amount was recorded as a reduction to cost of goods sold. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Refer
to Note&nbsp;2 for disclosure regarding the merger of Coca-Cola FEMSA and Panamco in 2003 and the recording of a $102&nbsp;million noncash pretax charge to the line
item equity income&#151;net. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>92</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=94,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=470834,FOLIO='92',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]FO1030A.;53',USER='NDEWIND',CD='26-FEB-2004;15:27' -->
<A NAME="page_fo1030_1_93"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the third quarter of 2002, our Company recorded a noncash pretax charge of approximately $33&nbsp;million related to our share of impairment and restructuring charges taken by
certain investees in Latin America. This charge was recorded in the line item equity income&#151;net. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
Company had direct and indirect ownership interests totaling approximately 18&nbsp;percent in Cervejarias Kaiser S.A. ("Kaiser S.A."). In March&nbsp;2002, Kaiser S.A. sold its
investment in Cervejarias Kaiser Brazil,&nbsp;Ltda to Molson&nbsp;Inc. ("Molson") for cash of approximately $485&nbsp;million and shares of Molson valued at approximately $150&nbsp;million.
Our Company's pretax share of the gain related to this sale was approximately $43&nbsp;million, of which approximately $21&nbsp;million was recorded in the line item equity income&#151;net,
and approximately $22&nbsp;million was recorded in the line item other income (loss)&#151;net. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the first quarter of 2002, our Company recorded a noncash pretax charge of approximately $157&nbsp;million (recorded in the line item other income (loss)&#151;net), primarily
related to the write-down of certain investments in Latin America. This write-down reduced the carrying value of the investments in Latin America to fair value. The charge was
primarily the result of the economic developments in Argentina during the first quarter of 2002, including the devaluation of the Argentine peso and the severity of the unfavorable economic outlook. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>NOTE&nbsp;17: STREAMLINING COSTS  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2003, the Company took steps to streamline and simplify its operations, primarily in North America and Germany. In North America, the Company integrated
the operations of three formerly separate North American business units&#151;Coca-Cola North America, Minute Maid and Fountain. In Germany, CCEAG took steps to improve its
efficiency in sales, distribution and manufacturing, and our German Division office also implemented streamlining initiatives. Selected other operations also took steps to streamline their operations
to improve overall efficiency and effectiveness. As disclosed in Note&nbsp;1, under SFAS No.&nbsp;146, a liability is accrued only when certain criteria are met. All of the Company's streamlining
initiatives met these criteria as of December&nbsp;31, 2003, and all related costs have been incurred as of December&nbsp;31, 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Employees
separated from the Company as a result of these streamlining initiatives were offered severance or early retirement packages, as appropriate, which included both financial and
nonfinancial components. The expenses recorded during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 included costs associated with involuntary terminations and other direct costs associated with
implementing these initiatives. As of December&nbsp;31, 2003, approximately 3,700 associates had been separated pursuant to these streamlining initiatives. Other direct costs included the relocation
of employees; contract termination costs; costs associated with the development, communication and administration of these initiatives; and asset write-offs. During 2003, the Company
incurred total pretax expenses related to these streamlining initiatives of approximately $561&nbsp;million, or $0.15 per share after tax. These expenses were recorded in the line item other
operating charges. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>93</FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>NOTE&nbsp;18: ACQUISITIONS AND INVESTMENTS  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2003, our Company's acquisition and investment activity totaled approximately $359&nbsp;million. These acquisitions included purchases of trademarks,
brands and related contractual rights of approximately $142&nbsp;million, none of which was individually significant. Refer to Note&nbsp;4. Other acquisition and investing activity totaled
approximately $217&nbsp;million, and with the exception of the acquisition of Truesdale, none was
individually significant. In March&nbsp;2003, our Company acquired a 100&nbsp;percent ownership interest in Truesdale from CCE for cash consideration of approximately $58&nbsp;million. Truesdale
owns a noncarbonated beverage production facility. The purchase price was allocated primarily to the property, plant and equipment acquired. No amount was allocated to intangible assets. Truesdale is
included in our North America operating segment. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2002, our Company's acquisition and investment activity totaled approximately $1,144&nbsp;million. Included in this $1,144&nbsp;million, our Company paid $544&nbsp;million
in cash and recorded a $600&nbsp;million note payable to finance the CCEAG acquisition described below. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
November&nbsp;2001, we entered into the Control and Profit and Loss Transfer Agreement ("CPL") with CCEAG. Under the terms of the CPL, our Company acquired management control of
CCEAG. In </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>94</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=96,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=603719,FOLIO='94',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]FO1030B.;15',USER='NDEWIND',CD='26-FEB-2004;15:27' -->
<A NAME="page_fo1030_1_95"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>November&nbsp;2001,
we also entered into a Pooling Agreement with certain share owners of CCEAG that provided our Company with voting control of CCEAG. Both agreements became effective in
February&nbsp;2002, when our Company acquired control of CCEAG for a term ending no later than December&nbsp;31, 2006. CCEAG is included in our Europe, Eurasia and Middle East operating segment.
As a result of acquiring control of CCEAG, our Company is working to help focus its sales and marketing programs and assist in developing the business. This transaction was accounted for as a business
combination, and the results of CCEAG's operations have been included in the Company's financial statements since February&nbsp;2002. Prior to February&nbsp;2002, our Company accounted for CCEAG
under the equity method of accounting. As of December&nbsp;31, 2002, our Company had an approximate 41&nbsp;percent ownership interest in the outstanding shares of CCEAG. In return for control of
CCEAG, pursuant to the CPL we guaranteed annual payments, in lieu of dividends by CCEAG, to all other CCEAG share owners. These guaranteed annual payments equal .76 euro for each CCEAG share
outstanding. Additionally, all other CCEAG share owners entered into either a put or a put/call option agreement with the Company, exercisable at any time up to the December&nbsp;31, 2006 expiration
date. In 2003, one of the other share owners exercised its put option that represented approximately 29&nbsp;percent of the outstanding shares of CCEAG. All payments related to the exercise of the
put options will be made in 2006. Our Company entered into either put or put/call agreements for shares representing an approximate 59&nbsp;percent interest in CCEAG. The spread in the strike prices
of the put and call options is approximately 3&nbsp;percent. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of the date of the transaction, the Company concluded that the exercise of the put and/or call agreements was a virtual certainty based on the minimal differences in the strike
prices. We concluded that either the holder of the put option would require the Company to purchase the shares at the agreed-upon put strike price, or the Company would exercise its call
option and require the share owner to tender its shares at the agreed-upon call strike price. If these puts or calls are exercised, the actual transfer of shares would not occur until the
end of the term of the CPL. Coupled with the guaranteed payments in lieu of dividends for the term of the CPL, these instruments represented the financing vehicle for the transaction. As such, the
Company determined that the economic substance of the transaction resulted in the acquisition of the remaining outstanding shares of CCEAG and required the Company to account for the transaction as a
business combination. Furthermore, the terms of the CPL transferred control and all of the economic risks and rewards of CCEAG to the Company immediately. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
present value of the total amount likely to be paid by our Company to all other CCEAG share owners, including the put or put/call payments and the guaranteed annual payments in lieu
of dividends, was approximately $905&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2003. This amount increased from the initial liability of approximately $600&nbsp;million due to the accretion of the
discounted value to the ultimate maturity of the liability, as well as approximately $239&nbsp;million of translation adjustment related to this liability. This liability is included in the line
item other liabilities. The accretion of the discounted value to its ultimate maturity value is recorded in the line item other income (loss)&#151;net, and this amount was approximately
$51&nbsp;million and $38&nbsp;million, respectively, for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
July&nbsp;2002, our Company and Danone Waters of North America,&nbsp;Inc. ("DWNA") formed a new limited liability company, CCDA, for the production, marketing and distribution of
DWNA's bottled spring and source water business in the United States. In forming CCDA, DWNA contributed assets of its retail bottled spring and source water business in the United States. These assets
include five production facilities, a license for the use of the Dannon and Sparkletts brands, as well as ownership of several value brands. Our Company made a cash payment to acquire a controlling
51&nbsp;percent equity interest in CCDA and is also providing marketing, distribution and management expertise. This transaction was accounted for as a business combination, and the </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>95</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=97,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=124911,FOLIO='95',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]FO1030B.;15',USER='NDEWIND',CD='26-FEB-2004;15:27' -->
<A NAME="page_fo1030_1_96"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>consolidated
results of CCDA's operations have been included in the Company's financial statements since July&nbsp;2002. This business combination expanded our water brands to include a national
offering in all sectors of the water category with purified, spring and source waters. CCDA is included in our North America operating segment. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
January&nbsp;2002, our Company and CCBPI finalized the purchase of RFM Corp.'s ("RFM") approximate 83&nbsp;percent interest in CBC, a publicly traded Philippine beverage company.
CBC is an established carbonated soft-drink business in the Philippines and was included in our Asia operating segment. The original sale and purchase agreement with RFM was entered into in
November&nbsp;2001. As of the date of this sale and purchase agreement, the Company began supplying concentrate for this operation. The purchase of RFM's interest was finalized on January&nbsp;3,
2002. In March&nbsp;2002, a tender offer was completed with our Company and CCBPI acquiring all shares of the remaining minority share owners except for shares representing a 1&nbsp;percent
interest in CBC. This transaction was accounted for as a business combination, and the results of CBC's operations were included in the Company's financial statements from January&nbsp;2002 to
March&nbsp;2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company and CCBPI agreed to restructure the ownership of the operations of CBC, and this transaction was completed in April&nbsp;2003. This transaction resulted in the Company
acquiring all the trademarks of CBC and CCBPI owning approximately 99&nbsp;percent of the outstanding shares of CBC. Accordingly, CBC was deconsolidated by the Company. No gain or loss was recorded
by our Company upon completion of the transaction, as the fair value of the assets exchanged was approximately equal. Additionally, there was no impact on our cash flows related to this transaction. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
Company acquired controlling interests in CCDA and CBC for total combined consideration of approximately $328&nbsp;million. As of December&nbsp;31, 2003, the Company allocated
approximately $56&nbsp;million of the purchase price for these acquisitions to goodwill and $208&nbsp;million to other indefinite-lived intangible assets, primarily trademarks, brands and
licenses. This goodwill is all related to the CCDA acquisition and is allocated to our North America operating segment. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
combined 2002 net operating revenues of CCEAG, CBC and CCDA were approximately $1.3&nbsp;billion. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2001, our Company's acquisition and investment activity totaled approximately $651&nbsp;million. In February&nbsp;2001, our Company reached an agreement with Carlsberg for the
dissolution of CCNB, a joint venture bottler in which our Company had a 49&nbsp;percent ownership interest. At that time, CCNB had bottling operations in Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Finland and
Iceland. Under this agreement with Carlsberg, our Company acquired CCNB's Sweden and Norway bottling operations in June&nbsp;2001, increasing our Company's ownership in those bottlers to
100&nbsp;percent. Carlsberg acquired CCNB's Denmark and Finland bottling operations, increasing Carlsberg's ownership in those bottlers to 100&nbsp;percent. Pursuant to the agreement, CCNB sold
its Iceland bottling operations to a third-party group of investors in May&nbsp;2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
March&nbsp;2001, our Company signed a definitive agreement with La Tondena Distillers,&nbsp;Inc. ("La Tondena") and San Miguel to acquire carbonated soft-drink, water
and juice brands for $84&nbsp;million. CCBPI acquired the related manufacturing and distribution assets from La Tondena for $63&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
July&nbsp;2001, our Company and San Miguel acquired CCBPI from Coca-Cola Amatil. Upon the completion of this transaction, our Company owned 35&nbsp;percent of the
common shares and 100&nbsp;percent of the Preferred B shares, and San Miguel owned 65&nbsp;percent of the common shares of CCBPI. Additionally, as a result of this transaction, our Company's
interest in Coca-Cola Amatil was reduced from approximately 38&nbsp;percent to approximately 35&nbsp;percent. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>96</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=98,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=1042393,FOLIO='96',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]FO1030B.;15',USER='NDEWIND',CD='26-FEB-2004;15:27' -->
<A NAME="page_fo1030_1_97"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
December&nbsp;2001, our Company completed a cash tender offer for all outstanding shares of the common stock of Odwalla,&nbsp;Inc. This acquisition was valued at approximately
$190&nbsp;million with our Company receiving an ownership interest of 100&nbsp;percent. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
the first half of 2001, in separate transactions, our Company purchased two bottlers in Brazil: Refrescos Guararapes&nbsp;Ltda. and Sucovalle Sucos e Concentrados do Vale S.A. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
acquisitions and investments have been accounted for by either the purchase method or equity method of accounting, as appropriate. Their results have been included in our financial
statements from their respective dates of acquisition using the appropriate method of accounting. Assuming the results of these businesses had been included in operations commencing with 2001, pro
forma financial data would not be required due to immateriality. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>NOTE&nbsp;19: OPERATING SEGMENTS  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our Company's operating structure includes the following operating segments: North America; Africa; Asia; Europe, Eurasia and Middle East; Latin America; and
Corporate. North America includes the United States, Canada and Puerto Rico. Prior-period amounts have been reclassified to conform to the current-period presentation. </FONT></P>

<UL>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The business of our Company is nonalcoholic beverages. Our operating segments derive a majority of their revenues from the manufacture and sale of beverage
concentrates and syrups and, in some cases, the sale of finished beverages. The following table summarizes the contribution to net operating revenues from Company operations (in millions): </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Method of Determining Segment Profit or Loss  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management evaluates the performance of our operating segments separately to individually monitor the different factors affecting financial performance. Segment
profit or loss includes substantially all the segment's costs of production, distribution and administration. Our Company typically manages and evaluates equity investments and related income on a
segment level. However, we manage certain significant investments, such as our equity interests in CCE, at the Corporate segment. Our Company manages income taxes on a global basis. We manage
financial costs, such as exchange gains and losses and interest income and expense, on a global basis at the Corporate segment. Thus, we evaluate segment performance based on profit or loss before
income taxes and cumulative effect of accounting change. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>97</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=99,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=441472,FOLIO='97',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]FO1030B.;15',USER='NDEWIND',CD='26-FEB-2004;15:27' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_fp1030_1_98"> </A> </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Information about our Company's operations by operating segment is as follows (in millions): </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH WIDTH="37%" ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH WIDTH="6%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=1>North<BR>
America<BR></FONT>
<BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH WIDTH="4%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=1>Africa<BR></FONT>
<BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH WIDTH="5%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=1>Asia<BR></FONT>
<BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH WIDTH="7%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=1>Europe,<BR>
Eurasia&nbsp;&amp;<BR>
Middle<BR>

<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=101,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=399753,FOLIO='99',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]FP1030A.;24',USER='ARUSS',CD='26-FEB-2004;15:27' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_fq1030_1_100"> </A> </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>Report of Independent Auditors  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B> Board of Directors and Share Owners<BR>  </B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>The Coca-Cola Company  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of The Coca-Cola Company and subsidiaries as of December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002, and
the related consolidated statements of income, share-owners' equity, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2003. Our audits also included the financial
statement schedule listed in the Index at Item&nbsp;15(a). These financial statements and schedule are the responsibility of the Company's management. Our responsibility is to express an opinion on
these financial statements and schedule based on our audits. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
conducted our audits in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted in the United States. Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable
assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement. An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial
statements. An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation. We believe
that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
our opinion, the financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the consolidated financial position of The Coca-Cola Company and
subsidiaries at December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002, and the consolidated results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2003, in
conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States. Also, in our opinion, the related financial statement schedule, when considered in relation to the basic financial
statements taken as a whole, presents fairly in all material respects the information set forth therein. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
discussed in Notes 1, 4 and 13 to the Consolidated Financial Statements, in 2002 the Company changed its method of accounting for goodwill and other intangible assets and changed its
method of accounting for stock-based compensation. As discussed in Notes 1 and 10 to the Consolidated Financial Statements, in 2001 the Company changed its method of accounting for derivative
instruments and hedging activities. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>100</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=102,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=928691,FOLIO='100',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]FQ1030A.;21',USER='NDEWIND',CD='26-FEB-2004;15:33' -->
<A NAME="page_fq1030_1_101"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>REPORT OF MANAGEMENT<BR>  </B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>The Coca-Cola Company and Subsidiaries</I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
are responsible for the preparation and integrity of the Consolidated Financial Statements appearing in our Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K. The financial statements were prepared
in conformity with generally accepted accounting principles appropriate in the circumstances and, accordingly, include certain amounts based on our best judgments and estimates. Financial information
in this Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K is consistent with that in the financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
are responsible for maintaining a system of internal accounting controls and procedures to provide reasonable assurance that assets are safeguarded and that transactions are
authorized, recorded and reported properly. Internal accounting controls include disclosure controls and procedures designed to provide reasonable assurance that information required to be disclosed
is appropriately recorded, summarized and reported. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
internal accounting control system is augmented by a program of internal audits and appropriate reviews by management, written policies and guidelines, careful selection and training
of qualified personnel and a written Code of Business Conduct adopted by our Company's Board of Directors, applicable to all Company Directors and all officers, employees of our Company and our
subsidiaries. In our opinion, our Company's internal accounting controls provide reasonable assurance that assets are safeguarded against material loss from unauthorized use or disposition and that
the financial records are reliable for preparing financial statements and other data and for maintaining accountability of assets. In addition, in our opinion, our Company's disclosure controls and
procedures provide reasonable assurance that appropriate information is accumulated and communicated to senior management to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosures. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Audit Committee of our Company's Board of Directors, composed solely of Directors who are independent in accordance with the requirements of the New York Stock Exchange listing
standards and the Company's Corporate Governance Guidelines, meets with the independent auditors, management and internal auditors periodically to discuss internal accounting controls and auditing and
financial reporting matters. The Committee reviews with the independent auditors the scope and results of the audit effort. The Committee also meets periodically with the independent auditors and the
chief internal auditor without management present to ensure that the independent auditors and the chief internal auditor have free access to the Committee. Our Audit Committee's Report can be found in
the Company's annual proxy statement. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
independent auditors, Ernst&nbsp;&amp; Young LLP, are appointed by the Audit Committee of the Board of Directors, subject to ratification by our Company's share owners. Ernst&nbsp;&amp;
Young LLP is engaged to audit the Consolidated Financial Statements of The Coca-Cola Company and subsidiaries and conduct such tests and related procedures as it deems necessary in
conformity with generally accepted auditing standards. The opinion of the independent auditors, based upon their audits of the Consolidated Financial Statements, is contained in this Annual Report. </FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Certain amounts previously reported in our 2003 Quarterly Reports on Form&nbsp;10-Q were reclassified to conform to our year-end 2003 presentation. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the first quarter of 2003, the Company reached a settlement with certain defendants in a vitamin antitrust litigation matter. The Company received a settlement relating to this
litigation of approximately $52&nbsp;million on a pretax basis. Refer to Note&nbsp;16. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2003, the Company took steps to streamline and simplify its operations, primarily in North America and Germany. Selected other operations also took steps to streamline their
operations to improve overall efficiency and effectiveness. The pretax expense of these streamlining initiatives for the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2003, June&nbsp;30, 2003,
September&nbsp;30, 2003 and December&nbsp;31, 2003 was $159&nbsp;million, $70&nbsp;million, $43&nbsp;million and $289&nbsp;million, respectively. Refer to Note&nbsp;17. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective
May&nbsp;6, 2003, one of our Company's equity method investees, Coca-Cola FEMSA, S.A. de C.V. ("Coca-Cola FEMSA") consummated a merger with another of
the Company's equity method investees, Panamerican Beverages,&nbsp;Inc. During the third quarter of 2003, our Company recorded a pretax noncash charge to equity income&#151;net of
$95&nbsp;million primarily related to Coca-Cola FEMSA streamlining initiatives and impairment of certain intangible assets. During the fourth quarter of 2003, our Company recorded a
pretax noncash charge of $7&nbsp;million related solely to the streamlining and integration of these operations. Refer to Note&nbsp;2. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the fourth quarter of 2003, we favorably resolved various tax matters (approximately $50&nbsp;million), partially offset by additional taxes primarily related to the repatriation of
funds. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective
January&nbsp;1, 2002, our Company adopted Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;142, "Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets." For the Company's intangible
assets, the cumulative effect of this change in accounting principle was a decrease to net income after taxes in the first quarter of 2002 of approximately $367&nbsp;million. For the Company's
proportionate share of its equity method investees, the cumulative effect of this change in accounting principle was a decrease to net income after taxes in the first quarter of 2002 of approximately
$559&nbsp;million. Refer to Note&nbsp;4. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
first quarter of 2002 included a noncash pretax charge of approximately $157&nbsp;million primarily related to the write-down of our investments in Latin America. Refer
to Note&nbsp;16. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the first quarter of 2002, Cervejarias Kaiser S.A. sold its investment in Cervejarias Kaiser Brazil,&nbsp;Ltda to Molson&nbsp;Inc. ("Molson") for cash of approximately
$485&nbsp;million and shares of Molson valued at approximately $150&nbsp;million. Our Company's pretax share of the gain related to this sale was approximately $43&nbsp;million. Refer to
Note&nbsp;16. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
third quarter of 2002 includes a noncash pretax charge of approximately $33&nbsp;million related to our proportionate share of impairment and restructuring charges taken by certain
investees in Latin America. Refer to Note&nbsp;16. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>102</FONT></P>

NAME="page_fu1030_1_103"> </A> </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="fu1030_glossary"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_fu1030_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>GLOSSARY    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>As
used in this report, the following terms have the meanings indicated. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Bottling Partner or Bottler:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>businesses that buy concentrates, beverage bases or syrups from the Company, convert them into finished
packaged products and sell them to customers. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Carbonated Soft Drink:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>nonalcoholic carbonated beverage containing flavorings and sweeteners. Excludes, among others, waters and flavored
waters, juices and juice drinks, sports drinks, and teas and coffees. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>The Coca-Cola System:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>the Company and its bottling partners. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Company:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>The Coca-Cola Company together with its subsidiaries. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Concentrate:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>material manufactured from Company-defined ingredients and sold to bottlers to prepare finished beverages through the addition
of sweeteners and/or water and marketed under trademarks of the Company. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Consumer:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>person who drinks Company products. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Cost of Capital:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>after-tax blended cost of equity and borrowed funds used to invest in operating capital required for business. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Customer:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>retail outlet, restaurant or other operation that sells or serves Company products directly to consumers. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Derivatives:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>contracts or agreements, the value of which may change based on changes in interest rates, exchange rates, prices of
securities, or financial or commodity indices. The Company uses derivatives to reduce our exposure to adverse fluctuations in interest and exchange rates and other market risks. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Dividend Payout Ratio:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>cash dividends on common stock divided by net income. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Fountain:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>system used by retail outlets to dispense product into cups or glasses for immediate consumption. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Gallons:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>unit of measurement for concentrates, syrups, beverage bases, finished beverages and powders (in all cases, expressed in
equivalent gallons of syrup) for all beverage products which are reportable as unit case volume. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Gross Profit Margin:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>gross profit divided by net operating revenues. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Market:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>when used in reference to geographic areas, territory in which the Company and its bottling partners do business, often defined by
national boundaries. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Net Capital:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>share-owners' equity added to net debt. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Net Debt:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>debt less the sum of cash, cash equivalents and current marketable securities. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Noncarbonated Beverages:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>nonalcoholic noncarbonated beverages including, but not limited to, waters and flavored waters, juices and juice
drinks, sports drinks, and teas and coffees. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Operating Margin:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>operating income divided by net operating revenues. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Per Capita Consumption:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>average number of servings consumed per person, per year in a specific market. Per capita consumption of Company
products is calculated by multiplying our unit case volume by 24, and dividing by the population. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Return on Capital:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>income before changes in accounting principles (adding back interest expense, net of related taxes) divided by average
total capital. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Return on Common Equity:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>income before changes in accounting principles divided by average common share-owners' equity. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>103</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=105,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=650240,FOLIO='103',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]FU1030A.;22',USER='MKEANE',CD='25-FEB-2004;12:59' -->
<A NAME="page_fu1030_1_104"> </A>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Serving:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>eight U.S. fluid ounces of a finished beverage. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Syrup:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>concentrate mixed with sweetener and water, sold to bottlers and customers who add carbonated water to produce finished carbonated
soft drinks. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Total Capital:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>share-owners' equity plus interest-bearing debt. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Total Market Value of Common Stock:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>stock price as of a date multiplied by the number of shares outstanding as of the same date. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Unit Case:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>unit of measurement equal to 192 U.S. fluid ounces of finished beverage (24 servings). </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Unit Case Volume, or Volume:&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>the number of unit cases (or unit case equivalents) of Company trademark or licensed beverage products
directly or indirectly sold by the Coca-Cola system to customers. Volume primarily consists of beverage products bearing Company trademarks. Also included in volume are certain products
licensed to our Company or owned by our bottling partners, for which our Company provides marketing support and derives profit from the sales. Such products licensed to our Company or owned by our
bottling partners account for a minimal portion of total unit case volume. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>104</FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="fw1030_item_9._changes_in_and_disagre__ite03576"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_fw1030_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>ITEM 9. CHANGES IN AND DISAGREEMENTS WITH ACCOUNTANTS ON ACCOUNTING AND FINANCIAL DISCLOSURE    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Not applicable. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="fw1030_item_9a._controls_and_procedures"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_fw1030_2"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>ITEM 9A. CONTROLS AND PROCEDURES    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company, under the supervision and with the participation of its management, including the Chief Executive Officer and the Chief Financial Officer, evaluated
the effectiveness of the design and operation of the Company's "disclosure controls and procedures" (as defined in Rule&nbsp;13a-15(e) under the Securities Exchange Act) as of the end of
the period covered by this report. Based on that evaluation, the Chief Executive Officer and the Chief Financial Officer concluded that the Company's disclosure controls and procedures are effective
in timely making known to them material information relating to the Company and the Company's consolidated subsidiaries required to be disclosed in the Company's reports filed or submitted under the
Exchange Act. There has been no change in the Company's internal control over financial reporting during the quarter ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 that has materially affected, or is reasonably
likely to materially affect, the Company's internal control over financial reporting. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="ja1030_part_iii"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_ja1030_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>PART III    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="ja1030_item_10._directors_and___ja102272"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_ja1030_2"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>ITEM 10. DIRECTORS AND EXECUTIVE OFFICERS OF THE REGISTRANT    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The information under the headings "Board of Directors" and "Section&nbsp;16(a) Beneficial Ownership Reporting Compliance," and the information under the
subheading "Information about the Board and Corporate Governance&#151;The Audit Committee," in the Company's 2004 Proxy Statement is incorporated herein by reference. See Item X in
Part&nbsp;I of this report for information regarding executive officers of the Company. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company has adopted a code of business conduct and ethics applicable to the Company's Directors, officers (including the Company's principal executive officer, principal financial
officer and controller) and employees, known as the Code of Business Conduct. The Code of Business Conduct is available on the Company's website. In the event that we amend or waive any of the
provisions of the Code of Business Conduct applicable to our principal executive officer, principal financial officer or controller, we intend to disclose the same on the Company's website at
www.coca-cola.com. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="ja1030_item_11._executive_compensation"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_ja1030_3"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>ITEM 11. EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The information under the principal heading "EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION," under the subheading "Information about the Board and Corporate
Governance&#151;Director Fees," and under the heading "Compensation Committee Interlocks and Insider Participation," in the Company's 2004 Proxy Statement is incorporated herein by reference. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="ja1030_item_12._security_ownership_of__ite04004"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_ja1030_4"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>ITEM 12. SECURITY OWNERSHIP OF CERTAIN BENEFICIAL OWNERS AND MANAGEMENT AND RELATED STOCKHOLDER MATTERS    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The information under the headings "Equity Compensation Plan Information," "Ownership of Equity Securities in the Company," "Principal Share Owners" and
"Ownership of Securities in Investee Companies" in the Company's 2004 Proxy Statement is incorporated herein by reference. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="ja1030_item_13._certain_relati__ja102115"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_ja1030_5"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>ITEM 13. CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED TRANSACTIONS    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The information under the headings "Information about the Board and Corporate Governance," "Certain Transactions and Relationships" and "Compensation Committee
Interlocks and Insider Participation," and the information under the principal heading "CERTAIN INVESTEE COMPANIES," in the Company's 2004 Proxy Statement is incorporated herein by reference. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="ja1030_item_14._principal_accountant_fees_and_services"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_ja1030_6"> </A>

<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=118,EFW="2126594",CP="THE COCA-COLA COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=652244,FOLIO='S-3',FILE='DISK033:[04ATA0.04ATA1030]MA1030A.;36',USER='NDEWIND',CD='26-FEB-2004;20:16' -->

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="ke1030_exhibit_31.1"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_ke1030_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>EXHIBIT 31.1    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><B>CERTIFICATIONS  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>I,
Douglas N. Daft, Chairman, Board of Directors, and Chief Executive Officer of The Coca-Cola Company, certify that: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>1.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>I
have reviewed this annual report on Form&nbsp;10-K of The Coca-Cola Company;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>2.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Based
on my knowledge, this report does not contain any untrue statement of a material fact or omit to state a material fact necessary to make the statements made, in light of the
circumstances under which such statements were made, not misleading with respect to the period covered by this report;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>3.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Based
on my knowledge, the financial statements, and other financial information included in this report, fairly present in all material respects the financial condition, results of
operations and cash flows of the registrant as of, and for, the periods presented in this report;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>4.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
registrant's other certifying officer(s) and I are responsible for establishing and maintaining disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Exchange Act
Rules&nbsp;13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e)) for the registrant and have:
<BR><BR></FONT>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(a)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Designed
such disclosure controls and procedures, or caused such disclosure controls and procedures to be designed under our supervision, to ensure that material information relating
to the registrant, including its consolidated subsidiaries, is made known to us by others within those entities, particularly during the period in which this report is being prepared;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(b)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>[Reserved.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>]
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(c)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Evaluated
the effectiveness of the registrant's disclosure controls and procedures and presented in this report our conclusions about the effectiveness of the disclosure controls and
procedures, as of the end of the period covered by this report based on such evaluation; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(d)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Disclosed
in this report any change in the registrant's internal control over financial reporting that occurred during the registrant's most recent fiscal quarter (the registrant's
fourth fiscal quarter in the case of an annual report) that has materially affected, or is reasonably likely to materially affect, the registrant's internal control over financial reporting; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD></DL>
</DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>5.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
registrant's other certifying officer(s) and I have disclosed, based on our most recent evaluation of internal control over financial reporting, to the registrant's auditors and
the audit committee of the registrant's board of directors (or persons performing the equivalent functions):
<BR><BR></FONT>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(a)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>All
significant deficiencies and material weaknesses in the design or operation of internal control over financial reporting which are reasonably likely to adversely affect the
registrant's ability to record, process, summarize and report financial information; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(b)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Any
fraud, whether or not material, that involves management or other employees who have a significant role in the registrant's internal control over financial reporting. </FONT></DD></DL>
</DD></DL>
</UL>
<BR>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><B>CERTIFICATIONS  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>I,
Gary P. Fayard, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of The Coca-Cola Company, certify that: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>1.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>I

on my knowledge, this report does not contain any untrue statement of a material fact or omit to state a material fact necessary to make the statements made, in light of the

on my knowledge, the financial statements, and other financial information included in this report, fairly present in all material respects the financial condition, results of

<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>4.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
registrant's other certifying officer(s) and I are responsible for establishing and maintaining disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Exchange Act
Rules&nbsp;13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e)) for the registrant and have:
<BR><BR></FONT>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(a)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Designed
such disclosure controls and procedures, or caused such disclosure controls and procedures to be designed under our supervision, to ensure that material information relating
to the registrant, including its consolidated subsidiaries, is made known to us by others within those entities, particularly during the period in which this report is being prepared;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(b)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>[Reserved.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>]
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(c)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Evaluated

<BR><BR></FONT></DD></DL>
</DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>5.</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
registrant's other certifying officer(s) and I have disclosed, based on our most recent evaluation of internal control over financial reporting, to the registrant's auditors and

<BR><BR></FONT>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(a)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>All
significant deficiencies and material weaknesses in the design or operation of internal control over financial reporting which are reasonably likely to adversely affect the
registrant's ability to record, process, summarize and report financial information; and

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><B>EXHIBIT 32.1  </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="ki1030_certification_pursuant_to_18_u__cer03819"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_ki1030_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>CERTIFICATION PURSUANT TO<BR>  18 U.S.C. SECTION 1350,<BR>  AS ADOPTED PURSUANT TO<BR>  SECTION 906 OF THE SARBANES-OXLEY ACT OF 2002    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
connection with the Annual Report of The Coca-Cola Company (the "Company") on Form&nbsp;10-K for the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 (the "Report"), I, Douglas N.
Daft, Chairman, Board of Directors, and Chief Executive Officer of the Company and I, Gary P. Fayard, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of the Company, each certify, pursuant to 18
U.S.C. Section&nbsp;1350, as adopted pursuant to Section&nbsp;906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, that: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(1)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>to
my knowledge, the Report fully complies with the requirements of Section&nbsp;13(a) or 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(2)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>the
information contained in the Report fairly presents, in all material respects, the financial condition and results of operations of the Company. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
